Title: Ashina Bakery ‘Ashibei’ (Signature Pizza & Curry Bread)

- March 2022 (2nd edition; information collected in 2022)

Place:
- Ashina Bakery Ashibei, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A bakery where the map says the morning line never ends. Recommended items include their signature pizza with shredded cheese and gorgonzola, and a special curry bread with a crispy crust and plenty of filling.
- Hours: 8:00–16:00 (until sold out)

title: 2025 Yokosuka Chuo Illumination Photo Contest
place:
Along Chuo Odori Avenue, Y Deck, and the plaza under Y Deck (Yokosuka-Chuo area)
Address area: Wakamatsu-cho 2-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa (and surrounding spots)
text:
Title: 2025 Yokosuka Chuo Illumination Photo Contest

Datetime:
- Dec 1, 2025 (Mon) – Jan 31, 2026 (Sat)

Place:
- Along Chuo Odori Avenue, Y Deck, and the plaza under Y Deck (Yokosuka-Chuo area)
- Address area: Wakamatsu-cho 2-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa (and surrounding spots)

Detail:
- Take your best winter illumination photo in the Yokosuka-Chuo area and submit it via Instagram.
- How to enter:
1) Follow the official Instagram account: @yokosukaxmaslights
2) Photograph the illuminations in the Yokosuka-Chuo area during the entry period
3) Post your photo on Instagram tagging @yokosukaxmaslights and add the hashtag “#IllumiYokosuka2025” (original Japanese hashtag: #イルミヨコスカ2025) plus one theme hashtag below.
- Themes (choose one):
- Nostalgic: #ノスタルジック
- Romantic: #ロマンティック
- Winter Cool: #ウィンタークール
- Everyone can join as long as you agree to the entry rules.

Attention:
- Winners will be contacted by Instagram Direct Message during February 2026, so make sure your account can receive DMs.
- Prizes (approx.):
- Grand Prize: Selectable Domestic Wagyu (catalog gift, about ¥30,000) – 1 winner
- Special Prize: 47CLUB catalog gift (about ¥10,000) – 1 winner per theme
- Honorable Mention: Prizes worth about ¥5,000 – 2 winners per theme
- Please read the contest rules before posting.
- Access: Keikyu “Yokosuka-Chuo” Station (East Exit), about 0–5 minutes on foot.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/photocon-illumi.html
- Official Instagram: https://instagram.com/yokosukaxmaslights

Tags: Yokosuka, Yokosuka-Chuo, Winter illumination, Photo contest, Instagram, Night view, Kanagawa

title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Guided Tour)
datetime: January 4 (Sun), meet at 09:30 / finish around 11:30 (held in light rain; canceled in severe weather)
place:
Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Line “Uraga” Station)
Disbanding point: In front of Uraga Community Center
Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Guided Tour)

Datetime:
- January 4 (Sun), meet at 09:30 / finish around 11:30 (held in light rain; canceled in severe weather)

Place:
- Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Line “Uraga” Station)
- Disbanding point: In front of Uraga Community Center
- Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A guided walking tour of a historic brick-built dry dock constructed in 1899 (Meiji 32) and closed in 2003 (Heisei 15).
- Learn about the site’s shipbuilding/maintenance history (over 1,000 ships built on the slipway; many repairs and inspections in the dock) and view the dock from multiple angles.
- Course (approx. 1.0 km): briefing → jib crane → dock side → pump house → flap gate → tower crane remains → stairs → dock bottom → stairs → dock head → Uraga Community Center annex (local history museum). (The Brick Dock Utilization Center may be added if available.)

Attention:
- Advance application required (online via the organizer’s site); no postcard applications.
- Capacity: 50 people; lottery if oversubscribed.
- Fee: JPY 500 (elementary school students are free when accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: drink, rain gear, mask, and any other necessities.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Transportation and any admission fees are additional.
- Accident compensation is limited to the organizer’s insurance coverage.
- Organizer / inquiries: NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office (TEL: 046-822-8256).

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-245.html
- Organizer / application information: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: yokosuka, uraga, guided-tour, history, industrial-heritage, dry-dock, walking-tour

title: YOKOSUKA Fire Department Parade 2026 (消防出初式)
place:
Parade route: Yokosuka Chuo Odori (from the National Route 16 side toward Yokosuka-Chuo Station)
Fureai Plaza: Station-front plaza under the Yokosuka-Chuo Station Y-Deck
text:
Title: YOKOSUKA Fire Department Parade 2026 (消防出初式)

Datetime:
- 2026-01-11 (Sun)  09:30–11:30

Place:
- Parade route: Yokosuka Chuo Odori (from the National Route 16 side toward Yokosuka-Chuo Station)
- Fureai Plaza: Station-front plaza under the Yokosuka-Chuo Station Y-Deck

Detail:
- A New Year’s fire services parade held on Yokosuka Chuo Odori, featuring marching by the Fire Volunteer Band and Women’s Firefighting Team, plus a parade of fire and rescue vehicles.
- Vehicle parade participants include fire volunteer corps vehicles, Yokosuka City Fire Department vehicles, and U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base fire vehicles.
- Includes a ladder-truck rescue demonstration and other dynamic rescue performances.
- The Fureai Plaza area offers fire vehicle displays, fire volunteer recruitment promotion, and fire prevention/disaster preparedness outreach.

Attention:
- Road closure: Yokosuka Chuo Odori will be closed in both directions from 09:30 to 11:30 (the reopening time may be earlier).
- Viewing from the Y-Deck is not allowed for safety reasons.
- No dedicated parking for the parade—use public transportation.
- Event-day status can be confirmed from 08:00 via the Yokosuka City Call Center (Tel: 046-822-4000).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/syoubou-parade.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/7410/syoubou/topics/r7pare-do.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Festival, Parade, Fire Department, New Year, Family-friendly, Traffic restriction

text:
Title: Explore the Uraga Road “Mitori-ezu” Map (Part 4) — Guided Walking Tour

Datetime:
- Saturday, January 31, 2026
- Check-in: 9:00–9:30 (meet at **JR Kinugasa Station**)
- End: around 14:30 (disband at **Keikyu Otsu Station**)
- Cancelled in rain / severe weather

Place:
- Meeting point: **JR Kinugasa Station**, Yokosuka, Kanagawa (Kinugasa Sakaemachi 2-chome 1)
- Disband: **Keikyu Otsu Station**, Yokosuka, Kanagawa
- Route crosses the central Miura Peninsula through cut-throughs and hilly terrain

Detail:
- A guided tour that follows the “Uraga Road Mitori-ezu” route from Kinugasa toward Otsu, enjoying natural scenery and historic landforms.
- Distance: about **7.0 km** (recommended for fairly fit walkers).
- Planned course (in order):
- JR Kinugasa Station → Koshin-ji Temple → “Hoto” Crossroads → Kugō Kōshin-to Stone Monument Group → Kugō Shrine → Sōgen-ji (former site) → Myōshin-ji Temple → Negishi 5-chome Kōshin-to → Tenjinzaka Slope → Aizen Inari Shrine → Otsu Sports Park (lunch) → Otsu Jinya Ruins → Otsu Suwa Shrine → Shinsei-ji Temple → Shinraku-ji Temple → Keikyu Otsu Station

Attention:
- **Advance registration required**; application deadline: **Saturday, January 24**.
- Capacity: **50 people** (lottery if oversubscribed).
- Fee: **500 JPY** (elementary school students are free if accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: lunch, drink, umbrella, and a ground sheet (plus anything else you may need).
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are **not included**.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Accident coverage is limited to the scope of the insurance held by the guide association.
- Event status can also be checked via the “Yokosuka Calendar” or Yokosuka City Call Center (046-822-4000, 7:15–20:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/4.html
- Application/official tour site: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Guided walking tour, Uraga Road, Miura Peninsula, Nature scenery, Historic route, Temples and shrines, Hiking (7 km), January 2026

Detail:
- A planned guided walking tour (Sports/Outdoor) and the 5th session in the “Tour the Western Uraga Road” series.
- The tour aims for the former Uraga Magistrate’s Office site as the goal.
- Highlights include the historic Yanozu-zaka slope (once considered a difficult pass), a stop at Nishi Kanou Shrine (associated with prayers for the revival/restoration of the Uraga brick dock), and reporting at the Uraga Magistrate’s Office site after completing the route.
- Distance & difficulty: about 4.0 km; suitable for general participants.
- Capacity: 50 participants.
- Fee: 500 JPY (elementary school students accompanied by a guardian are free).
- What to bring: drinks, packed lunch, rain gear, and anything else you may need.

Attention:
- Advance application required. Application deadline: Sat, Feb 14 (year implied: 2026).
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are NOT included and must be paid separately.
- If there are too many applicants, participants will be selected by lottery.
- The tour may be cancelled in rain or severe weather.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Accident compensation is limited to the insurance coverage held by the Yokosuka City Guide Association.
- After disbanding: from Konya-cho Bus Stop
- To Uraga Station: ~5 minutes, 200 JPY
- To Keikyu Kurihama Station: ~12 minutes, 220 JPY

Link:

title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Uraga Renga Dock Tour)
place:
Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Uraga Station on the Keikyu Line)
Finish: In front of Uraga Community Center (Annex / Local History Museum)
Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Uraga Renga Dock Tour)

Datetime:
- February 15 (Sunday), 09:30 (meet) – around 11:30 (finish)
- Application deadline: February 2 (Monday)

Place:
- Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Uraga Station on the Keikyu Line)
- Finish: In front of Uraga Community Center (Annex / Local History Museum)
- Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A guided tour that lets you experience the history of a brick-built dry dock. The dock was constructed in 1899 (Meiji 32) and was used until it closed in 2003 (Heisei 15). While the slipway built more than 1,000 ships, the dock was used for many repairs and inspections. You will view the site from many angles to appreciate its scale and engineering heritage.
- Walking course (about 1.0 km): meeting/orientation → jib crane → dock side wall → pump house → flap gate → tower crane remains → stairs → dock bottom → stairs → dock head → Uraga Community Center (disband). (If available, the Brick Dock Utilization Center may be added.)

Attention:
- Advance registration required (no postcard applications).
- Light rain: tour proceeds. Severe weather: canceled.
- Capacity: 50 people. If there are too many applications, participants will be chosen by lottery.
- Fee: 500 JPY (elementary school children are free if accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: drinks, rain gear, mask, and anything else you think you may need.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers). Transportation costs and any admission fees are not included.
- In case of an accident, compensation is limited to the scope of the organizer’s insurance.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-254.html
- Official site (application): http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html
- Organizer (NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office): TEL 046-822-8256 / FAX 046-827-1682
- Day-of status check: Yokosuka Call Center 046-822-2500 (07:15–20:00)

title: Guided Tour: Explore Miura Clan Historic Sites and Buddhist Statues
place:
Meeting point: (Keikyu Bus) Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop (衣笠城址バス停)
Address (meeting area): 4 Kinugasa-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Dismissal point: (Keikyu Bus) Iwato Bus Stop (岩戸バス停)
text:
Title: Guided Tour: Explore Miura Clan Historic Sites and Buddhist Statues

Datetime:
- Wednesday, February 4, 2026 09:00–14:30

Place:
- Meeting point: (Keikyu Bus) Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop (衣笠城址バス停)
- Address (meeting area): 4 Kinugasa-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Dismissal point: (Keikyu Bus) Iwato Bus Stop (岩戸バス停)

Detail:
- This is a planned guided walking tour visiting places associated with the Miura clan—often described as one of the largest warrior groups in Sagami Province—who played an important role in the founding era of the Kamakura shogunate.
- You will also visit temples to view nationally important Buddhist statues (Important Cultural Properties) and related historic sites.
- Capacity: 50 people (advance application required)
- Walking distance: about 5.0 km (recommended for strong walkers)
- What to bring: lunch and drinks; other items you may need (example: a walking stick)
- Participation fee: 500 JPY (elementary school students accompanied by a guardian: free)
- Additional temple viewing fees (separate): Daizen-ji 200 JPY, Seiun-ji 200 JPY, Mangan-ji 300 JPY (total 700 JPY)
- Deadline: Wednesday, January 28
- How to apply: From the official site’s top page, select “Tour Application” and apply for the relevant tour.
- Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins → Daizen-ji (main hall) → Mansho-ji (Miura Yoshiaki’s grave) → Yakkoji-ato site → Chikadono Shrine → Oyabe Neighborhood Hall (lunch) → Seiun-ji (main hall, Takimi Kannon, graves of three generations of the Miura clan) → Harakiri-matsu Park → Mangan-ji (Kannon & Jizo statues, grave of Sahara Yoshitsura) → Iwato Bus Stop

Attention:
- Transportation and admission/viewing fees are not included (paid separately).
- If there are many applications, participants may be selected by lottery.
- Please wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- In case of an accident, compensation is limited to the scope of the insurance held by the City Guide Association.
- Note: The nationally designated Important Cultural Property statue of Miura Yoshiaki at Mansho-ji is currently under repair and cannot be viewed.
- To the meeting point:
- Yokosuka-Chuo Station Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop: ~17 min, 280 JPY
- YRP Nobi Station Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop: ~18 min, 290 JPY
- After dismissal:
- Iwato Bus Stop → Kita-Kurihama Station Bus Stop: ~10 min, 260 JPY

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-249.html
- Official site (application): http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html
- Contact (NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office): TEL +81-46-822-8256
- Yokosuka Call Center (event-day confirmation): +81-46-822-4000 (7:15–20:00)

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Guided tour, Walking tour, Miura clan, Kamakura period, Historic sites, Temples, Buddhist statues, Cultural heritage

title: Miura Clan Heritage Stamp Rally (Yokosuka City)
place: Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (23 Miura Clan–related locations across the city)
text:
Title: Miura Clan Heritage Stamp Rally (Yokosuka City)

Datetime:
- 2025-11-14 (Fri) to 2026-01-04 (Sun)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (23 Miura Clan–related locations across the city)

Detail:
- This is a city-wide stamp rally themed around the Miura clan, a warrior family that supported the founding of the Kamakura shogunate. Participants visit designated “stamp spots” and collect digital stamps using their smartphone’s GPS. After collecting stamps, you can apply for a prize drawing (luxury gifts are mentioned). The route is designed to be explored with a convenient digital map, and representative spots include Manshoji Temple, Manganji Temple, Arasaki Coast (Nagai Castle area), and Arai Castle area.

Attention:
- Participation is free, but you are responsible for smartphone data charges and transportation costs.
- Some “castle” spots are medieval sites; there may be no castle buildings or structures to see at those locations.
- You will need a smartphone with location services (GPS) enabled to obtain stamps.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/miuraitizoku.html
- Official stamp rally info / digital map: https://www.cocoyoko.net/special/miuraichizoku.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Miura clan, Kamakura period, history, stamp rally, digital map, temples, castle ruins

Detail:
- A guided walking and ferry tour that explores Yokosuka’s modern industrial/military heritage (starting from the former Yokosuka Ironworks area) while enjoying views of modern Japanese and U.S. naval vessels.
- The tour includes a visit to Sarushima, described as the only natural island in Tokyo Bay, and features island exploration plus lunch time on the island.
- Walking distance: approx. 5.0 km (general fitness level).

Attention:

title: Yokosuka Local Foods Gourmet (Yokosuka “Jibamono” Local Produce & Seafood)
datetime: Accessed on 2025-12-26 (timestamp shown on the source PDF capture: 10:16 PM)
place: Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Yokosuka Local Foods Gourmet (Yokosuka “Jibamono” Local Produce & Seafood)

Datetime:
- Accessed on 2025-12-26 (timestamp shown on the source PDF capture: 10:16 PM)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Yokosuka is described as a “treasure house of ingredients,” surrounded by sea and greenery, where you can enjoy seasonal local produce and seafood at peak freshness.
- **Seafood highlights (Umi no Sachi / “Bounty of the Sea”)**
- Famous local fish include “the three major local fish of Yokosuka,” plus bluefish such as sardine (iwashi), mackerel (saba), and horse mackerel (maaji). Because it’s a producing area, some catches can be eaten raw on the same day they are landed.
- Recommended local items also include local octopus, shellfish like turban shell (sazae), and Shonan shirasu.
- “Himodori katsuo” (day-return bonito), known for a chewy texture, is highlighted as a luxury seasonal specialty available from summer to autumn.
- Seaweeds (nori, wakame, kombu, hijiki, etc.) are described as top-quality in freshness, color, aroma, texture, and flavor.
- **Produce highlights (Daichi no Megumi / “Bounty of the Land”)**
- “Yokosuka vegetables” are characterized by natural sweetness, influenced by mineral-rich soils and sunlight, with freshness that makes the difference noticeable.
- Representative items include cabbage, daikon radish, and pumpkin. Seasonal examples:
- Spring: potatoes, onions
- Summer: watermelon, cucumber, tomato, eggplant
- Autumn: mandarin oranges (mikan), sweet potatoes
- Winter: strawberries, napa cabbage, cauliflower, broccoli
- “Early-spring cabbage” is described as sweet and tender despite being harvested in winter; “spring cabbage” becomes even sweeter and is recommended for raw dishes like salads.
- Yokosuka also produces colorful, unusual Western vegetables used in Italian/French cuisine, emphasizing diversity, vibrant colors, and high quality.
- Local eggs, meat, and milk are mentioned, and sweets made with local eggs are suggested as ideal souvenirs.
- **Where to try/buy**
- The page introduces city-registered “local production for local consumption” shops (restaurants, lodging facilities, processed food sellers, supermarkets, retailers, and direct-sale outlets) that actively handle local products so visitors can “taste” and “buy” Yokosuka’s local ingredients.

Attention:
- Seasonality matters: availability and peak taste vary by season (especially bonito in summer–autumn and produce by season).
- Fresh seafood may be served raw only when conditions are right; follow each shop’s guidance and any food safety notes.
- Check shop hours/stock in advance if you are visiting specifically for a seasonal item.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/gourmet/yokosuka_localfoods.html
- (Related on-page references) “Yokosuka Umi no Sachi / Daichi no Megumi” local production & consumption guidebook (web version) and the city’s “local production for local consumption” shop listings.

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japanese local food, Seafood, Local produce, Seasonal specialties, Farm-to-table, Shirasu, Bonito, Yokosuka vegetables

title: Curry Town Yokosuka (Yokosuka Navy Curry)
place: Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Curry Town Yokosuka (Yokosuka Navy Curry)

Datetime:
- Accessed on 2025-12-26 22:16 (JST)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- “Curry Town Yokosuka” is a local food-and-tourism initiative built around the idea that Japanese curry became widely popular through the Imperial Japanese Navy, and that Yokosuka—historically a navy town—can promote itself as a “birthplace of curry culture.”
- The initiative traces back to December 1998, when a retiring Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) regional commander suggested using “curry” for local revitalization because of its naval roots.
- After research and planning by three parties—Yokosuka City Hall, the Yokosuka Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the JMSDF—the city decided to recreate historical navy-style curry for modern audiences.
- On May 20, 1999, Yokosuka officially declared itself a “Curry Town,” and the “Curry Town Yokosuka Promotion Committee” was launched.
- Today, visitors can enjoy a wide variety of curry-related foods beyond “Yokosuka Navy Curry,” including original curries created by local shops, curry bread, prepared dishes, and even curry-flavored sweets—making it a fun theme for a food-focused walk around the city.

Attention:
- Restaurant offerings and participation can change, so check the official site for the latest listings and event updates (including curry festival information).
- Curry varies widely by spice level and ingredients; if you have allergies or dietary restrictions, ask the shop staff before ordering.
- If you want to compare styles, try both “Yokosuka Navy Curry” and “Yokosuka JMSDF Curry” when available.

Link:
- Official page: [Curry Town Yokosuka (Yokosuka Gourmet / Yokosuka City Tourism Information)](https://www.cocoyoko.net/gourmet/curry.html)

title: Yokosuka Cherry Cheese Cake (Yokosuka Gourmet)
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Origin: U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base (produced as a Yokosuka gourmet brand)
text:
Title: Yokosuka Cherry Cheese Cake (Yokosuka Gourmet)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 22:16 (page capture time)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Origin: U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base (produced as a Yokosuka gourmet brand)

Detail:
- Yokosuka Cherry Cheese Cake is a local dessert brand inspired by an authentic New York–style cheesecake. It was produced by the U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base (home to about 20,000 Americans) and the recipe was provided on November 18, 2009.
- Compared with typical “New York cheesecake” in Japan, it uses a generous amount of cream cheese for a rich, creamy taste and features a fragrant graham-cracker crust.
- The “cherry” topping represents Japan’s iconic sakura and symbolizes Japan–U.S. friendship, giving the dessert its name “Cherry Cheese Cake.”
- Key points highlighted in the report:
- High-quality cream cheese is the star ingredient.
- Because it is simple (few additional ingredients), the flavor becomes especially dense and rich.
- New York–style baking uses a water bath and low temperature to steam-bake it slowly, aiming for a creamy finish.
- A lightly sweet cherry topping is simmered carefully until it thickens, leaving a refreshing aftertaste.

Attention:
- This is a rich, dairy-heavy dessert. If you have allergies (dairy, wheat/gluten from graham crackers), confirm ingredients with each shop.
- Availability and serving style may differ by store—check before visiting, especially on busy weekends/holidays.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/gourmet/cherrycheesecake.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, gourmet, dessert, cheesecake, new-york-style, cherry, sakura, japan-us-friendship, local-brand

datetime:

Late 1940s (Hamburgers were served at the EM Club near Shioiri Station, introducing the food to local civilians.)
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Around the U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base / Dobuita Street area (many participating restaurants are located near the base)
text:
Title: Yokosuka Navy Burger (Yokosuka Gourmet)

Datetime:
- 2008-11-19 (The traditional U.S. Navy hamburger recipe was provided from U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base to Yokosuka City.)
- Late 1940s (Hamburgers were served at the EM Club near Shioiri Station, introducing the food to local civilians.)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Around the U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base / Dobuita Street area (many participating restaurants are located near the base)

Detail:
- **What it is:** “Yokosuka Navy Burger” is a local gourmet brand based on a traditional U.S. Navy-style hamburger recipe. The city promotes it so visitors can enjoy an authentic “American-style” burger at participating shops around the base area.
- **Why Yokosuka:** Yokosuka has long been a gateway for American culture through the U.S. Navy presence. The report notes that hamburgers became widely familiar in Yokosuka, and the city is considered one of the places where hamburgers first took root in Japan.
- **Origin story (local branding):**
- A traditional Navy burger recipe—popular at base open-house events—was officially provided to Yokosuka City on **November 19, 2008**, as a symbol of friendship and joint local revitalization efforts.
- **Taste & style (key characteristics):**
- Extremely simple, **focused on the natural flavor of beef**.
- Uses **100% beef with a high lean ratio**, cooked simply so it tastes like “steak in a bun.”
- Topped with **fresh onion and tomato**.
- You season it yourself with **ketchup and mustard**, in a classic American style.
- TSUNAMI / TSUNAMI BOX
- Dobuita Shokudo “Perry”
- Hungry’s
- Younger Than
- HONEY BEE (including the Yokosuka Port Market shop)
- LAUNA (local gourmet restaurant)
- YOKOSUKA Shell
- HONCH SHELL
- Grill & Cafe Alfred
- SURF TACO

Attention:
- The “Navy Burger” style is intentionally simple—don’t expect heavy sauces or many toppings by default.
- Some of the most “authentic” experiences are associated with **U.S. Navy base public open days**, but the city also promotes burgers sold at **restaurants outside the base** around the base area.
- Check each restaurant’s opening hours, menu availability, and access conditions (especially on event days).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/gourmet/yokosuka_navyburger.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, local-gourmet, navy-burger, american-culture, dobuita-street, shioiri, 100-percent-beef

title: Kimamani Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 01 — Oppama Station (Yokosuka Route Museum)
place:
Oppama Station area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Keikyu Line)
Main areas covered: Oppama waterfront and historic townscape; Takatori-yama (Mt. Takatori) hiking area; Jinmu-ji / Jinmuji Station area
text:
Title: Kimamani Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 01 — Oppama Station (Yokosuka Route Museum)

Place:
- Oppama Station area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Keikyu Line)
- Main areas covered: Oppama waterfront and historic townscape; Takatori-yama (Mt. Takatori) hiking area; Jinmu-ji / Jinmuji Station area

Detail:
- **What this is:** A walking & hiking leaflet from the *Yokosuka Route Museum* project, which frames Yokosuka as “one big museum” by connecting many small “satellite” spots (history, culture, nature) into routes.
- **Start/Goal:** Oppama Station (round trip)
- **Highlights:** local shrines and temples, small port scenery, historical markers
- **Start:** Oppama Station
- **Goal:** Jinmuji Station
- **Highlights:** old road atmosphere, Mt. Takatori views, rock-carved Buddha, Jinmu-ji Temple
- **Kaizan Green Space (Kaizan Ryokuchi) area (Uragō-chō)** — A developing park area along the street from Oppama Station toward the sea. Monuments related to the former Imperial Japanese Navy are noted, and an observation point offers views over ships entering/leaving Yokosuka Port.
- **Tokyo Bay Third Sea Fort (Daisan Kaihō)** — Located inside Natsushima Urban Green Space (Yokosuka).
- Address: 2-26 Natsushima-chō, Yokosuka (inside Natsushima Urban Green Space)
- Open: 10:00–16:00 on the **first Sunday of each month**
- Contact: NPO Action Oppama / 046-866-2790
- **DOCK OF BAYSTARS YOKOSUKA** — The Yokohama DeNA BayStars’ training complex opened in July 2019. The leaflet notes an outdoor viewing space and nearby Yokosuka Stadium (farm team home) hosting around 30 Eastern League games per year.

Attention:
- **Hiking safety:** Mt. Takatori has steep/cliff sections—use proper footwear and allow extra time.
- **Rock climbing:** The leaflet states that rock climbing is prohibited in Takatori-yama Park unless registered with the local safety climbing association.
- **Limited opening:** Tokyo Bay Third Sea Fort is only open on the first Sunday each month (10:00–16:00).
- **Info freshness:** Prices/operating details are noted as “as of March 2024 (Reiwa 6)” in the brochure—verify before visiting.
- **Respectful visits:** Shrines/temples and the cemetery are sensitive places—follow local etiquette.

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourism Information (COCO YOKO): https://www.cocoyoko.net/
- Yokosuka Route Museum (official): https://routemuseum.jp/
- Multilingual guide page (Guideor): https://www.guidoor.jp/lp/4566
- NPO Action Oppama (Tokyo Bay Third Sea Fort info): http://www.action-oppama.org/
- Yokosuka local info (listed in brochure): https://www.sukaichi.com/

Tags: Yokosuka, Oppama, Kanagawa, Walking route, Hiking, Mount Takatori, Takatori-yama Park, Magaibutsu (rock carving), Shrines and temples, Waterfront / marina, Tokyo Bay Third Sea Fort, BayStars

title: Kimama-ni Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 02: Keikyu Taura Station → Anjinzuka Station → Hemi Station (Yokosuka Walking Guide)
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Area highlights: Nagaura Port / Taura / Anjinzuka / Hemi
text:
Title: Kimama-ni Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 02: Keikyu Taura Station → Anjinzuka Station → Hemi Station (Yokosuka Walking Guide)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Area highlights: Nagaura Port / Taura / Anjinzuka / Hemi

Detail:
- **Overview**
- This brochure proposes two walkable routes that combine **naval/industrial heritage** around Nagaura Port with **scenic viewpoints and seasonal flowers** (cherry blossoms and plums).
- **Recommended walking routes**
- **Course A (City walk: modern industrial heritage)**
- Approx. **4.6 km / ~1 h 35 min**
- Theme: A walk visiting modernization-era sites such as former Imperial Japanese Navy facilities around Nagaura Port.
- Example route: **Keikyu Taura Station → Former Navy Arsenal/Ordnance area → Navy Communications Education monument → JR Taura Station → Hiyou Tunnel → Anjindai Park → Anjinzuka Station**
- Notable stops (with brochure distances/times between points):
- Former Navy Arsenal/Ordnance area (**0.8 km / 17 min**): brick-built facilities and other naval-era buildings visible from the road.
- Navy Communications Education monument (**1.1 km / 22 min**): a site associated with the start of wireless telegraphy education (1901).
- JR Taura Station (**0.3 km / 6 min**): a rare station squeezed between tunnels; the platform is famously short for long trains.
- Hiyou Tunnel (**0.7 km / 15 min**): a military-use tunnel where rail and road ran side by side; freight trains used switchbacks and ammunition handling occurred inside.
- Anjindai Park (**1.0 km / 20 min**): viewpoints over Yokosuka Main Port and Aegis-equipped ships.
- Goal: Anjinzuka Station (**0.7 km / 15 min**)
- **Course B (Hiking + views: Tsukayama Park & Taura Ume-no-Sato)**
- Approx. **6 km / ~2 h 20 min**
- Theme: Crosses famous blossom spots (Tsukayama Park, Taura Ume-no-Sato) and follows an old road with panoramic views of **Tokyo Bay** and the **Bōsō Peninsula**.
- Example route: **Anjinzuka Station → Tsukayama Prefectural Park → Jusantoge Pass → Otasaka → Taura Ume-no-Sato → Observation Deck → Taura Post Office bus stop → Keikyu Taura Station**
- Notable stops (with brochure distances/times between points):
- Tsukayama Prefectural Park (**1.2 km / 30 min**): selected scenic area with broad views (port, Sarushima, Yokohama, etc.); a noted cherry-blossom spot and associated with Miura Anjin (William Adams).
- Jusantoge Pass (**0.7 km / 15 min**): a historic “Uraga-michi” route created during the Edo period; described as one of the toughest sections on the old road.
- Otasaka (**0.5 km / 10 min**)
- Taura Ume-no-Sato (**0.8 km / 25 min**): seasonal flowers including about **2,000 plum trees** and **75,000 narcissus**; views toward Tokyo Bay.
- Observation Deck (**0.4 km / 12 min**): views of landmarks such as the Tokyo Bay Aqua-Line and the Bōsō Peninsula.
- Taura Post Office bus stop (**1.0 km / 20 min**)
- Goal: Keikyu Taura Station (**1.3 km / 25 min**)
- **Featured tourism spots (spot list in the brochure)**
- **Modernization heritage around Nagaura Port**: structures tied to industry/transport/civil engineering; naval-era facilities remain from late Meiji through the postwar era.
- **Former Navy Supply Department: Nagaura Warehouse**: historic logistics warehouses once used for fuel, food, clothing, etc.
- **Rail spur line**: remnants of a branch line running from JR Taura Station toward the warehouse area.
- **Nanagama Tunnel**: one of several historic tunnels near JR Taura Station on the Yokosuka side.
- **Arai Horikiri Waterway (canal)**: dug in **1885–1889** to improve sea traffic between Nagaura and Yokosuka ports; the surrounding area later became part of fuel-related facilities.
- **Nango Park**: known for cherry-blossom season events.
- **Jodo-ji Temple (recommended spot)**: a temple associated with Miura Anjin; includes cultural assets and seasonal openings/services.
- **Taura Ume-no-Sato (recommended spot)**: plum/narcissus gardens with scenic viewpoints.
- **Best seasons mentioned/implicit in the brochure**
- **Late March to early April**: cherry blossoms (e.g., Tsukayama Park; seasonal festivals).
- **Plum season**: Taura Ume-no-Sato (plum trees and narcissus).

Attention:
- **Jusantoge Pass** is described as a tough mountain path on a historic route—plan for elevation changes and allow enough time.
- Parts of the walk include **tunnels and roads**—stay alert and follow local traffic rules.
- Information in the brochure reflects the situation **as of June 2024**; confirm the latest details before visiting.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism information: www.cocoyoko.net
- Local shop/community information: www.sukaichi.com
- Yokosuka City Call Center (tourism/information): +81-46-822-4000
- Yokosuka City Guide Association (NPO): +81-46-822-8256
- Yokosuka City Tourism Division: +81-46-822-8124

title: Kimaman(i) Stroll 05: Uraga Station — Walk Uraga, the Port Where Japan Opened to the World
place: Uraga Station area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Kimaman(i) Stroll 05: Uraga Station — Walk Uraga, the Port Where Japan Opened to the World

Place:
- Uraga Station area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- **Overview:** A self-guided walking course around Uraga, known as the place where Commodore Perry arrived. The route includes a short **ferry crossing** that connects West and East Uraga and highlights local history, shipbuilding, and town scenery.
- **Suggested loop distance/time:** **about 5 km / about 1 hour 20 minutes** (Uraga Station → Ferry → Uraga Station).
- Return to **Uraga Station**.
- A historic shipbuilding/repair area that produced and repaired many vessels for over a century (around 1,000 ships).
- The brochure notes that **Japan’s first Western-style warship “Hōō-maru”** was built here in **1854**, and **Kanrin Maru** was repaired here before its Pacific crossing.
- Remains such as a **crane built in 1945** and a **dry dock built in 1899** can still be seen (viewing is generally from outside).
- A small ferry affectionately called **“Ponpon-bune.”** Records go back to around **1725**, and it has about **300 years** of history as a daily lifeline between East and West Uraga.
- The crossing takes **about 3 minutes**. If the boat is on the opposite bank, you can press the **call button** and it will come.
- The route is named **“Uraga Kaidō”** and is described as a rare **municipal road on water (Route No. 2073)**.
- Hours: **7:00–17:00**
- Fare: **Adults 400 yen**, **elementary & junior high students 200 yen**, **bicycles etc. 50 yen**
- Service may stop due to bad weather or vessel inspection/maintenance.
- **Nishiha Shrine:** A “wish-granting” shrine (title given after the wish was fulfilled) with **230+ carvings** around the hall—some depict flowers/birds said not to have been introduced to Japan at the time.
- **Tip from the map:** If you take the ferry and visit **both** the West and East “Kanae” shrines, your love wish *might* come true (a playful local tradition).
- **Tametomo Shrine:** Features a statue of **Minamoto no Tametomo**. The local **“Tiger Dance”** tradition is said to have been brought when the magistrate’s office was moved from Shimoda (Izu).
- Operated from **1720 to 1868** (about 150 years), handling ship inspections and maritime rescue. Today, only remnants such as stonework of the moat remain.
- An L-shaped pier near the East side. The brochure notes its connection to post–World War II repatriation, when many returnees first stepped onto Japanese soil here.
- Built in **1648** as a beacon for ships entering/leaving Uraga Port; the light (rapeseed oil) is said to have reached **7.4 km**.
- It was maintained for about **220 years** until **1872**, later reconstructed in **1988** on the original stone base.
- Decorative reliefs made with a trowel and plaster, common from the late Edo period onward. The brochure points out that Uraga still has several examples, reflecting the town’s prosperity and skilled plaster artisans.
- Completed in **1895** to defend the mouth of Tokyo Bay, equipped with **six 28 cm howitzers**.
- Designated a **National Historic Site** in **2015** (check opening conditions in advance).

Attention:
- **Uraga Dock:** Entry is generally restricted; plan to view from outside designated areas.
- **Ferry:** Runs **7:00–17:00** and may be suspended in storms or for maintenance—build flexibility into your plan.
- **Chiyogasaki Battery Ruins:** Public access/opening conditions can change; verify before visiting.
- The course includes stairs and some slopes; wear comfortable shoes and allow extra time if you stop for photos.

Link:
- Source brochure (PDF): (see citation in the chat response)
- Yokosuka tourism portal: cocoyoko.net
- Yokosuka local guide portal: sukaichi.com
- Yokosuka tourism call center: 046-822-4000
- Uraga Ferry (operator contact): 046-825-7144
- Uraga Community Center Annex: 046-842-4121

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Walking route, Historical port, Perry, Kanrin Maru, Ferry, Shrines, Shipbuilding, Fort, Kote-e

title: Kimamani Walk (No. 06): Keikyu Kurihama Station — Kurihama Flower Park & Perry Landing Area (Yokosuka)
place: Kurihama area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (around Keikyu Kurihama Station, Kurihama Flower Park, Kurihama Port / Beach).
text:
Title: Kimamani Walk (No. 06): Keikyu Kurihama Station — Kurihama Flower Park & Perry Landing Area (Yokosuka)

Place:
- Kurihama area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (around Keikyu Kurihama Station, Kurihama Flower Park, Kurihama Port / Beach).

Detail:
- **Overview**
- This leaflet is a walking guide for the Kurihama district, centered on **Keikyu Kurihama Station**, with recommended routes and major sightseeing spots.
- **Recommended walking routes**
- **Course A (loop): “Kurihama Flower Park & the town of Perry’s landing”**
- Concept: From Keikyu Kurihama Station → Kurihama Flower Park → Kurihama beach/shore area associated with Commodore Perry’s landing → return to the station along the river.
- Total: **about 4.5 km / about 1 hour**
- Step-by-step (distance / walking time between points):
1) Kurihama Tenjin Shrine → 0.6 km (7 min)
2) Kurihama Flower Park → 0.7 km (9 min)
3) Sumiyoshi Shrine → 0.5 km (8 min)
4) Perry Park & Perry Memorial Museum → 0.7 km (9 min)
5) Kaikoku Bridge → 0.4 km (6 min)
6) Meoto Bridge → 1.1 km (15 min)
7) Back to Keikyu Kurihama Station → 0.5 km (5 min)
- **Course B (to Uraga): “Old road walking route”**
- Concept: From Keikyu Kurihama Station → follow the old road toward **Uraga** (recommended for confident walkers).
- Total: **about 4 km / about 1 hour**
- Notes: The leaflet suggests also checking the separate “Kimamani Walk: Uraga Station” guide for more detail.
- **Key sightseeing spots in/around Kurihama**
- **Kurihama Flower Park (Kurihama Hana-no-Kuni) & Herb Garden**
- A large park where you can enjoy seasonal flowers (spring poppies, autumn cosmos). The park also has a famous **Godzilla-themed slide** in the “Adventure Land” area.
- Herb Garden highlights: ~80 kinds / ~8,000 herb plants. Lavender is best from spring to early summer; sage varieties are highlights in autumn. The adjacent greenhouse features plants like hibiscus.
- Practical info:
- Address: Shinmei-cho 1, Yokosuka
- Tel: 046-833-8282
- Closed: none
- Parking (regular car): 630 JPY per entry
- Admission: free (some facilities may charge)
- Herb Garden hours: 9:00–17:00 (free)
- **Perry Park & Perry Memorial Museum**
- Commemorates Commodore Perry’s landing at the Kurihama shoreline; the park has a landing monument, and the museum exhibits historical materials and models.
- Museum info:
- Tel: 046-834-1351
- Hours: 9:00–16:30
- Closed: Mondays (or the next day if Monday is a holiday) and year-end/New Year
- Park: open year-round (24 hours)
- **Kaikoku Bridge**
- A viewpoint where you can watch the Tokyo Bay Ferry entering/leaving Kurihama Port and ships passing offshore. Fireworks may be held during the Perry Landing Commemoration Ceremony.
- **“Minato Oasis: Perry Kurihama” (Kurihama Port area)**
- Registered as a “Minato Oasis” in 2018, developed as a waterfront leisure spot around the port. Includes the Keikyu Kurihama Terminal area, ferry terminal, places to eat fresh seafood, and facilities with panoramic Tokyo Bay views.
- **Tokyo Bay Ferry**
- About a 40-minute ferry trip across Tokyo Bay to the Boso Peninsula; you can also watch large vessels traveling the Uraga Channel up close.
- Tel: 046-835-8855
- Parking: 1,000 JPY per day
- Adult fare: 1,000 JPY one-way (1,780 JPY round trip)
- Website: tokyowanferry.com
- **Jigen-in Temple**
- Known for a steep stone staircase (102 steps) leading to the main hall. During cherry blossom season, the temple grounds are illuminated for beautiful night viewing.
- **Sumiyoshi Shrine**
- Historically worshiped by the Miura clan as a guardian deity for their naval forces; they are said to have raised flags on pine trees at the summit to pray for lasting good fortune in battle.
- **JGSDF Kurihama Garrison (Japan Ground Self-Defense Force)**
- Originated from the former Imperial Japanese Navy Communications School; today it is a hub for communications/electronic warfare and information-related functions.
- On-site exhibits include a “History Hall” displaying communications equipment and a model exhibition room that explains the garrison’s history.
- PR office: 046-841-3300 (ext. 213)
- Visiting hours: 9:00–16:00 (closed on Saturdays and national holidays)
- Website: mod.go.jp/gsdf/sigsch/
- **Course A extra bridges & shrines**
- **Kurihama Tenjin Shrine**: said to have been founded by inviting a Tenmangu deity (linked to Fukushima Tenmangu in Osaka) during Edo-period land development works.
- **Meoto Bridge**: named after a pine tree on the central island that, seen from both sides, looks like a pair (“husband and wife”); also associated with local development history.

Attention:
- Walking times/distances are estimates from the leaflet; they vary by pace and detours.
- Opening hours/closures can change (especially museums and facilities). Confirm before visiting.
- Seasonal highlights:
- Jigen-in: cherry blossom illumination (spring).
- Kurihama Flower Park: poppy (spring) and cosmos (autumn), plus festival events such as flower-picking days.
- Some sites (e.g., the JGSDF facility) may have entry restrictions or security procedures.

Link:
- Yokosuka City Tourism Information (portal): cocoyoko.net
- Yokosuka City Tourism Call Center: +81-46-822-4000 (Open daily; weekdays 8:00–18:00, holidays 8:00–16:00)
- Yokosuka City Guide Association (NPO): +81-46-822-8256
- Yokosuka “Sukaichi” local shop info: sukaichi.com / Yokosuka Chamber of Commerce: +81-46-823-0421
- Tokyo Bay Ferry: tokyowanferry.com / +81-46-835-8855
- JGSDF Kurihama Garrison: mod.go.jp/gsdf/sigsch/

title: Kimamani Walk 07: Kita-Shiura Coast Road & Satoyama Path (YRP Nobi Station ↔ Keikyu Kurihama Station)
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
Main area: YRP Nobi Station / Yokosuka Research Park (YRP), Nobi Coast (Kita-Shiura Kaigan-dori), Kurihama (Perry Park area), Keikyu Kurihama Station.
text:
Title: Kimamani Walk 07: Kita-Shiura Coast Road & Satoyama Path (YRP Nobi Station ↔ Keikyu Kurihama Station)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
- Main area: YRP Nobi Station / Yokosuka Research Park (YRP), Nobi Coast (Kita-Shiura Kaigan-dori), Kurihama (Perry Park area), Keikyu Kurihama Station.

Detail:
- This brochure proposes two walkable routes that connect coastal scenery, local history, and a satoyama (traditional rural hillside) landscape.
- Course A (one-way, coastal → Kurihama)
- Overview: Walk along the Nobi coastline with sea breeze and open views to Tokyo Bay and the Boso Peninsula.
- Distance / time: ~8.4 km, ~2 hours.
- Suggested sequence (with approximate segment distances/times):
1) Hantaro Nagaoka Memorial Museum / Wakayama Bokusui Museum (from YRP Nobi Station: 1.1 km, 15 min)
2) Wakayama Bokusui “Couple Tanka” Monument (0.2 km, 5 min)
3) Kita-Shiura Kaigan-dori (Nobi coastal road) (0.6 km, 9 min)
- Highlights: ship traffic, wide bay views, and the seasonal “Onbe-yaki” bonfire ritual that prays for good health.
4) Sendagasaki Tunnel South Gate (2.6 km, 45 min)
- Note: Before WWII, naval trainees reportedly used the tunnel daily for drills—hence its nickname “Navy Tunnel.”
5) Sumiyoshi Shrine (1.1 km, 11 min)
6) Perry Park (0.7 km, 15 min)
7) Kaikoku Bridge (0.4 km, 6 min)
8) Meoto Bridge (1.1 km, 17 min)
- Goal: Keikyu Kurihama Station (0.6 km, 5 min)
- Course B (loop, YRP & nature)
- Overview: An out-and-back walk through Yokosuka Research Park (YRP), blending modern research facilities with quiet satoyama scenery.
- Distance / time: ~6.6 km, ~1 hour 30 min.
- Suggested sequence (with approximate segment distances/times):
1) Shimoda bus stop signal (0.9 km, 11 min)
2) YRP entrance (1.1 km, 23 min)
- YRP is one of Japan’s largest R&D hubs, with many ICT (wireless/telecom) companies and research institutes.
3) Hikari-no-Oka Mizube Park (0.8 km, 12 min)
- A wetland-style park designed to preserve nature; seasonal flowers and birdwatching are highlights.
4) YRP Center (0.6 km, 9 min)
5) Amaterasu-Omikami Shrine (1.7 km, 23 min)
- Goal: YRP Nobi Station (1.5 km, 20 min)
- Featured tourism spots (good “stop-by” highlights)
- Seseragi-no-Michi (Murmuring Stream Path): a small, circulating artificial stream with waterside plants and fish life.
- Satoyama Road: a peaceful countryside path with panoramic views, fields, and seasonal flowers.
- Karoutoyama Kofun (ancient burial mound): a ~10 m diameter round tumulus built around the early 7th century; artifacts are preserved/exhibited at Yokosuka City Museum of Nature and Human History.
- “Lucky Maneki-Fish” Monument (Nagahama Bridge): gold fish sculptures said to bring good luck in love—people place a 5-yen coin on the fish’s wide mouth.
- Wakayama Bokusui & Kita-Shiura Coast: the poet moved here in 1915 for his wife’s recuperation; two tanka monuments stand along the Nobi coast, including a “couple monument” with his poem on the front and his wife’s poem on the back.
- #Jihangun: an open-air art & photo spot on the seaside promenade, opened April 1, 2024.
- Recommended seasonal highlight
- Daffodils on “Kita-Shiura Kaigan-dori” (also called “Daffodil Road”): about one million daffodils bloom in early spring along the Nobi shoreline, with views across Tokyo Bay.
- Indoor exhibit (near YRP)
- Wireless History Exhibition Room (YRP Center Building No.1): exhibits items tracing wireless communications from the Perry era to today’s 5G, showcasing Yokosuka’s role in technological development.

Attention:
- Walking: Route distances are moderate (6.6–8.4 km). Wear comfortable shoes and plan for coastal wind and weather changes.
- Museum hours (Hantaro Nagaoka Memorial Museum / Wakayama Bokusui Museum):
- 09:00–16:00 (except lunch break); closed Mondays (or the next day if Monday is a holiday) and during year-end/New Year.
- Admission: free.
- Hikari-no-Oka Mizube Park opening hours:
- May–Aug 08:30–19:00; Sep 08:30–18:00; Oct–Apr 08:30–17:00; closed during year-end/New Year.
- Wireless History Exhibition Room:
- Weekdays 10:00–17:00; admission free.
- Some dates may be unavailable; tours/visits are handled via the website inquiry.
- Daffodil Road: best in early spring; daffodils are maintained by local volunteers—please respect plantings and stay on paths.
- Tourist info & guides:
- Yokosuka City Call Center: 046-822-4000 (Weekdays 08:00–18:00; Weekends/Holidays 08:00–16:00).
- Yokosuka City Guide Association (NPO): guided walk support may be available.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net (Yokosuka tourism information portal)
- https://yrp.co.jp/exhibitionhall/ (Wireless History Exhibition Room / YRP)
- https://www.sukaichi.com (Local shop & area info: “Yokosuka Ichiban”)

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Nobi, Kurihama, Tokyo Bay, Coastal walk, Walking route, Satoyama, Daffodils, History, Museum, Kofun, Photography, Art spot, YRP

title: Kimamani Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 08: Keikyu Nagasawa Station → Tsukuihama Station
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Miura Peninsula)
Walking route: Keikyu Nagasawa Station → Tsukuihama Station
text:
Title: Kimamani Sanpo (Casual Stroll) 08: Keikyu Nagasawa Station → Tsukuihama Station

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Miura Peninsula)
- Walking route: Keikyu Nagasawa Station → Tsukuihama Station

Detail:
- **Theme:** Hillside hiking and “taste hunting” (fruit picking).
- **Route outline:** Start at Keikyu Nagasawa Station, hike around Miura Fuji and Hotaiyama (Otsukayama), continue to Takeyama (200 m), then finish at Tsukuihama Station.
- **Distance / time:** about **7.8 km**, about **2 h 35 min**.
- **Key stops on the route:**
- **1. Tokoji Temple (東光寺)** (1.6 km / 20 min): Traditionally founded by the monk *Gyoki*. A historic temple with a traditional main hall and a Yakushi Nyorai statue; the area also keeps local historical graves and legends tied to the community.
- **2. Yokosuka Police Dog Training Center (横須賀警察犬大訓練所)** (1.0 km / 20 min): Training facilities on the way toward Miura Fuji.
- **3. Miura Fuji (Asama Shrine Inner Shrine) (三浦富士・浅間神社奥宮)** (0.4 km / 15 min, **183 m**): A summit shrine long revered by locals (including fishermen who used the mountain as a landmark). Great views over Sagami Bay and Tokyo Bay; on clear days you can also see Mt. Fuji and Yokosuka Research Park (YRP).
- **4. Hotaiyama / Otsukayama (砲台山・大塚山)** (0.6 km / 25 min): Named after a naval gun battery built in the early Showa era. The remains of a mortar-shaped emplacement and side holes believed to be ammunition storage are still visible. A fenced Japan Coast Guard receiving station with a parabolic antenna also stands on the summit.
- **5. Takeyama (武山)** (0.9 km / 20 min, **200 m**): A well-known viewpoint and azalea area (about **1,200** azaleas). Best season is mid‑April to early May, when the Takeyama azalea festival is held. From the rooftop observatory you can see Tokyo Bay, the Boso Peninsula, the Miura Peninsula, Izu Oshima, and (when the weather is clear) Mt. Fuji. The annual **Hatsufudo** day is **Jan 28**, when the main hall opens to the public and the approach is lined with stalls.
- **Local specialty:** “Takeyama Hatsufudo *fugashi*” (武山初不動の麩菓子) — a fish-shaped wheat‑gluten sweet on a bamboo skewer, sold during the Jan 28 event.
- **6. Tsukuihama Tourist Farm (津久井浜観光農園)** (1.7 km / 35 min): Fruit picking along the hiking course, plus a small shop selling farmer-made produce, pickles, and strawberry jam.
- **Strawberry picking:** early Jan – **May 5** (9:00–15:00)
- **Sweet potato digging:** mid Sep – mid Nov (9:00–15:00; weekends/holidays only)
- **Mandarin orange picking:** **Oct 20** – **Nov 30** (9:00–15:00)
- **Address:** 5-15-20 Tsukui, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
**Tel:** +81-46-849-4506 (weekday reception 9:00–15:00)

Attention:
- If you start from **Tsukuihama**, the climb to **Takeyama** is long and steep; the brochure recommends starting from **Keikyu Nagasawa Station**, especially for families.
- Fruit-picking dates can change depending on harvest conditions—check the farm’s latest information before visiting.
- Some sections are mountain trails. Wear proper shoes and bring water.

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourism Information: https://www.cocoyoko.net/
- Local shops / gourmet info (Yokosuka Ichi-ban): https://www.sukaichi.com/
- Yokosuka City Call Center: +81-46-822-4000 (Weekdays 8:00–18:00; Holidays 8:00–16:00)
- NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association: +81-46-822-8256

Tags: Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula, Keikyu Line, Hiking, Scenic views, Miura Fuji, Takeyama, Hotaiyama, Military history, Fruit picking, Strawberry picking, Tsukuihama Tourist Farm

title: Kimamani Walk 09: West Coast (Chojagasaki → Sajima), Yokosuka
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan — West Coast area (Chojagasaki / Akiya / Tateishi / Sajima).
The brochure also introduces nearby detours: Koyasu-no-Sato, Shonan International Village, Maedagawa Promenade, and Tenjinshima Coastal Nature Education Park.
text:
Title: Kimamani Walk 09: West Coast (Chojagasaki → Sajima), Yokosuka

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan — West Coast area (Chojagasaki / Akiya / Tateishi / Sajima).
- The brochure also introduces nearby detours: Koyasu-no-Sato, Shonan International Village, Maedagawa Promenade, and Tenjinshima Coastal Nature Education Park.

Detail:
- **Overview:** A seaside walking course along Yokosuka’s West Coast, passing scenic coastline, beaches, and cultural sites, and finishing at **Sajima Fishing Port**. Approx. **6.7 km / ~1 hour 30 min** (walking pace).
- **Access to the start:** Take a bus bound for **Chojagasaki** from **Zushi–Hayama Station**, and get off at the **Chojagasaki bus stop**.
- One of “Kanagawa’s 50 Scenic Views”; on clear days you can see **Enoshima**, the **Izu Peninsula**, and **Mt. Fuji**.
- A stone associated with safe childbirth; local tradition says touching it while praying can bring blessings.
- *Note:* Please view from the road; avoid entering private property.
- A coastline where natural shoreline remains; the “Tateishi” rock is about **12 m** high (circumference ~30 m), a well-known local landmark.
- Sunset views with Tateishi in the foreground are a highlight.
- A historic temple associated with Wada Yoshimori (the Wada clan). It is known for **five Buddha statues** (treasures of the temple).
- The site is also connected with **Hisoka Maejima** (“father of the postal system” in Japan), and his grave is located here.
- An old shrine said to have been enshrined by the Hojo clan (Kamakura period). People visit to pray for **safe childbirth** and protection.
- There is also an “Obidoki (pregnancy sash day) Child-Rearing Jizo” within the grounds.
- Worshiped as a shrine for **good relationships** and **maritime safety**. A seasonal festival includes a distinctive ritual performed along the shore.
- Tenjinshima and the surrounding sea are protected as a natural monument and scenic site in Kanagawa. A visitor center introduces local marine life and coastal nature.
- A lively port known for seafood from **Sagami Bay**, especially **shirasu (whitebait)**.
- **Koyasu-no-Sato (A):** A historic rural settlement (Edo period origins). Enjoy seasonal flowers and small unmanned stands selling local produce.
- **Shonan International Village (B):** A modern hillside area. On clear days you can enjoy wide views over the coast (Sagami Bay, Izu Peninsula, Mt. Fuji). Late April–early May is known for blooming azaleas.
- **Maedagawa Promenade (C):** A nature-rich riverside walk. The river is ~3.3 km long; about ~1.4 km is maintained as a promenade through forest and along the water, with birds, plants, and clear streams.
- **“Shonan Shirasu” (Recommended):** Fresh and processed seafood products from Sajima Fishing Port are popular souvenirs. “Shonan Shirasu” is introduced as a well-known brand, including mail-order purchases.

Attention:
- Some parts of the route run along roads—walk carefully and watch traffic, especially around Route 134.
- Coastal rocks and wet surfaces can be slippery; wear shoes with good grip and check sea/weather conditions.
- **Jorakuji Temple:** Viewing the Buddha statues requires **advance reservation** (visiting the grave does not).
- **Tenjinshima Visitor Center (Tenjinshima Coastal Nature Education Park):**
- Phone: **046-856-0177**
- Hours: **09:00–17:00** (Oct–Mar last entry **16:30**)
- Closed: **Mondays** (if Monday is a holiday, closed the following day), and **year-end/New Year**.
- **Facilities on the map:** Toilets, convenience stores, police boxes/stations, fire stations, and parking locations are marked in the brochure.

Link:
- Yokosuka City Tourism Information: **www.cocoyoko.net**
- Local shop / gourmet info site (“Yokosuka Ichiban”): **www.sukaichi.com**
- Yokosuka City Call Center: **046-822-4000** (Weekdays 08:00–18:00 / Weekends & holidays 08:00–16:00)
- NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association: **046-822-8256**
- “Shonan Shirasu” contacts (for details such as business hours / closing days, ask each shop):
- Yamamasa-maru: Yokosuka Sajima 1-25-15 / **046-857-6700**
- Hiratoshimaru: Yokosuka Sajima 2-4-1 / **046-801-1443**
- Monshiro-maru: Yokosuka Akiya 1-8-5 / **046-856-8625**

title: Misakiguchi Station Walk: Mito Fields → Arasaki Coast → Soleil Hill (Approx. 7.5 km / 2h 20m)
place: Misakiguchi Station (Keikyu Kurihama Line), Yokosuka City (Nagai / Mito / Arasaki area), Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Misakiguchi Station Walk: Mito Fields → Arasaki Coast → Soleil Hill (Approx. 7.5 km / 2h 20m)

Place:
- Misakiguchi Station (Keikyu Kurihama Line), Yokosuka City (Nagai / Mito / Arasaki area), Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- **Course overview**
- A relaxed walking route from Misakiguchi Station across the green plateau farmland of Mito, then along the Sagami Bay coastline, finishing at Nagai Seaside Park “Soleil Hill,” where you can enjoy views (Sagami Bay / Mt. Fuji / Shonan on clear days), BBQ, rides, and an open-air bath.
- **Recommended walking sequence (from the brochure map)**
- **1) Mito Farm Road (三戸の畑道)** — ~0.5 km / ~10 min from the station
- Seasonal farmland scenery; in clear weather you may see Mt. Fuji and coastal/island views from the higher ground.
- **2) Enjuji Temple (延寿寺)** — ~1 km / ~20 min
- **3) Entokuji Temple (円徳寺)** — ~2 km / ~35 min
- A seaside temple with local legends connected to a “sutra storehouse” that washed ashore; nearby is Akabane Inari, said to be a guardian deity linked to fishing.
- **4) Nagahama Beach (長浜海岸)** — ~0.5 km / ~10 min
- A wide sandy beach (locals call it “Naha-ma”); relaxed atmosphere, good for families. Rocky areas on both sides are suitable for snorkeling, and the area is popular for marine sports (e.g., kite/wind surfing) outside swimming zones during the beach season.
- **5) Nagai Seaside Park “Soleil Hill” (長井海の手公園 ソレイユの丘)** — ~1 km / ~20 min
- A large park with seasonal flower fields, big athletic/play areas, zipline, ferris wheel views, farm harvesting experiences, animal encounters (e.g., alpacas/capybaras), cooking/craft activities, restaurants/BBQ, camping, and a bathing facility.
- Phone: +81-46-857-2500
- Hours: 9:00–18:00 (Dec–Feb: 9:30–17:00)
- Closed: none (open daily) / Admission: free
- Parking: 1,050 JPY per standard car (per entry); ~1,700 spaces
- **6) Kanmyoji Temple (勧明寺)** — ~1 km / ~20 min
- **7) Kumano Shrine (熊野神社)** — ~0.5 km / ~5 min
- The main guardian shrine of the Nagai area; stone steps include engraved names linked to Edo-period fishing trades. On July 15 (annual festival day), a traditional dance offering “Jiya-odori” (a Yokosuka City-designated folk cultural asset) is dedicated.
- **8) Arasaki Park (荒崎公園)** — ~1 km / ~20 min
- Dramatic ria coastline and rocky shore scenery. From “Yuuhi no Oka” (Sunset Hill) you can enjoy wide views (Sagami Bay, Mt. Fuji and the Amagi range on clear days). Coastal plants are also a highlight; in mid-to-late autumn, daffodils begin blooming, and sunsets over the sea are especially atmospheric.
- **Extra stop ideas introduced in the brochure**
- **A) Bathing facility “Umi to Yuuhi no Yu” (海と夕日の湯)** (inside/near Soleil Hill)
- Open-air bath with Sagami Bay views (Mt. Fuji on clear days); indoor bath and sauna available.
- Hours: 14:30–20:30 (last entry 20:00)
- Fee: 700 JPY (junior-high and older) / 350 JPY (age 3–elementary)
- Bath set (admission + bath towel + face towel): 1,200 JPY
- **B) “Nagai no Michikiri” (長井の道切り)**
- A sacred rope custom: before the Sumiyoshi Shrine festival (May 15), a shimenawa is made and stretched at several points around Kanmyoji; straw-made items are hung on it. The tradition is said to protect the village from epidemics.
- **C) “Dondonbiki” (どんどんびき)**
- Along the Arasaki Park coast, waves carve a narrow inlet; it’s a photogenic rocky formation and a popular filming/photography spot.
- **D) Farmers’ market “Sukanagosso” (農作物直売所 すかなごっそ)**
- A direct-sales shop delivering fresh local produce from about 400 JA Yokosuka-Hayama producers; also sells flowers, eggs, handmade deli foods, and popular local soft-serve ice cream.
- Phone: +81-46-856-8314
- Hours: 9:30–18:00 (Mar–Oct) / 9:30–17:00 (Nov–Feb)
- Closed: Wednesday (open if it falls on a holiday) / Parking available
- **E) Nagai Fisheries Direct Sales Center (長井水産直売センター)**
- Sells Sagami Bay seafood at local prices, including processed/dried products; on weekends, don’t miss the limited “seafood bowl” offer (100 servings).
- Address: 5-24-7 Nagai, Yokosuka City
- Phone: +81-46-858-1020
- Hours: 8:30–16:30 (seasonal variation)
- Closed: Tuesday (open if it falls on a holiday) / Parking available

Attention:
- The full course is ~7.5 km; wear comfortable walking shoes and bring water.
- Coastal areas (Nagahama / Arasaki) can be windy and rocky—watch your footing, especially near waves.
- Facility hours and closing days vary by season (and may change). The brochure states the info is current as of June 2024.
- Please respect farmland paths—stay on routes and avoid entering fields.

Link:
- Yokosuka City Tourism Info: https://www.cocoyoko.net
- Yokosuka City Call Center (tourism inquiries): +81-46-822-4000 (Weekdays 8:00–18:00 / Weekends & holidays 8:00–16:00)
- Local shop/area info (“Sukaichi”): https://www.sukaichi.com

Tags: Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula, Misakiguchi Station, Walking course, Nagahama Beach, Arasaki Park, Soleil Hill, Local food, Seafood market, Farmers market

title: JR Yokosuka Station (JR横須賀駅)
place:
Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi (Yokosuka City)
text:
Title: JR Yokosuka Station (JR横須賀駅)

Place:
- Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi (Yokosuka City)

Detail:
- **Why it’s notable:** JR Yokosuka Station opened in June 1889 as the terminus of the Yokosuka Line and was considered nationally important up to the end of World War II. The current station building (rebuilt in 1940) retains much of the pre-rebuild appearance and has a classic, old-fashioned atmosphere.
- **Architecture & small details to look for:**
- It is known as one of the few stations in Japan without stairs.
- Some platform-roof support columns reuse old rails stamped “1886.”
- **Walking idea:** The station is positioned as a start/end point of Yokosuka’s “Umikaze no Michi” promenade (a sea-and-green 10,000-meter route).
- **Parking:** None.
- **Accessibility (barrier-free):**
- Elevators: No
- Escalators: No
- Step-free entrance measures (including ramps): Yes
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet: Yes
- Ostomate-accessible toilet: Yes
- Wheelchair rental: No
- Baby diaper-changing sheet: No (however, a simple bed is available and can be used for diaper changing)
- Accessible parking for people with disabilities: No
- Tactile guidance blocks: Yes
- Other: Braille fare table, baby chair, simple bed

Attention:
- There are **no elevators or escalators**, so plan routes and transfers accordingly.
- **No parking** at the station.
- Baby facilities are limited; diaper-changing is possible using the provided simple bed.
- For train times/fares or lost-and-found, contact JR East’s inquiry center (as listed on the source page).

Link:
- Official spot page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/yokosuka-st.html
- Related nearby spots listed on the source page: Verny Park, Verny Memorial Museum, Nanakama Tunnel (JR Taura Station), Thibaudier House (Yokosuka Modern Heritage Museum)

title: Yokosuka Genic Street (YOKOSUKA GENIC STREET)
place: Yokosuka East Coast (Shiioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Yokosuka Genic Street (YOKOSUKA GENIC STREET)

Place:
- Yokosuka East Coast (Shiioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A public-art project that revitalizes monuments along Yokosuka’s coastal street with newly created artworks, aiming to improve the streetscape and create a lively, walkable waterfront.
- In addition to wall art and monument art, events such as the “Yokosuka Coast Performance” (music/dance) are held to generate new vibrancy along the coast.
- Photo tip: Share your memories by posting photos taken here with the hashtag **#Sukageni** (Japanese: **#スカジェニ**).
- Notable artworks / areas:
- **First artwork (completed Nov 2020):** A 50-meter wave-shaped wall fountain monument redesigned by professional artists with the theme “LOVE,” designed as a photogenic spot.
- **SUKAGENI POP:** Selected from 23 public submissions; created by Ayumu Kusayama with the theme “Heart-thrilling Yokosuka.” Features a playful monument with a circular hole and pop motifs that may include “deep local references.” Located near Umikaze Park.
- **SUKAGENI MIX:** Created by Kanto Gakuin University Art Club students; eight wall panels featuring warm, hand-painted textures and vivid colors.
- **SUKAGENI LIFE:** Eight wall panels selected from about 80 works by users of local welfare facilities, themed around “Life,” “Pop,” and diversity.
- **SUKAGENI × LEEGET:** Artist LEEGET transformed the wall of a public toilet along the coast into a pop wall-art piece. (Wheelchair-accessible toilet available at this location.)
- Access (walk):
- ~15 minutes from **Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station**
- ~20 minutes from **Keikyu Kenritsu-Daigaku Station**
- Parking: None

Attention:
- Please do NOT use flash, drones, or similar filming equipment.
- Avoid actions that could damage the artwork (e.g., extreme close-ups that may cause contact or wear).
- Commercial photography is not permitted.
- When posting publicly, be careful about including other visitors in your photos.
- The city is not responsible for troubles between visitors or with passersby.
- The artworks are located along sidewalks—do not block pedestrian traffic while taking photos.
- Do not litter.
- Do not damage wall art, plantings, or related facilities.

Link:
- Official tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/sukageni.html
- City project page (related): https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/0810/10000me-toru.html
- Artist (LEEGET): https://www.instagram.com/leeget/  /  https://twitter.com/LEEGET
- Instagram (Yokosuka East Coast): https://www.instagram.com/yokosuka_higashikaigan/
- YouTube (related videos):
- https://youtu.be/JK1uy77_x8c
- https://youtu.be/r9eCZkFNZQ0

text:
Title: YOKOSUKA Naval Port Cruise (YOKOSUKA Gunkō Meguri)

Place:
- Boarding pier: Shiioiri Pier (behind “Coaska Bayside Stores”), Honcho 3-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Car navigation note (address input): 2-1-12 Honcho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Nearest stations:
- Keikyu Line: Shiioiri Station (about 5 minutes on foot)
- JR: Yokosuka Station (about 10 minutes on foot)

Detail:
- A harbor cruise where you can see many ships up close in Yokosuka Main Port and Nagaura Port, which are used by the U.S. Navy and the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force.
- The course departs from the pier behind Coaska Bayside Stores and makes a full loop through Yokosuka Main Port, Nagaura Port, and the Arai-bori canal/waterway.
- Enjoy Yokosuka’s historic “naval port city” atmosphere from the sea (Yokosuka developed as a naval port from the late Edo period).

Attention:
- Price (standard): JPY 2,200 (elementary school children: JPY 1,100). Prices may vary by day/season.
- Children: One preschool child rides free per paying adult; if the number of preschool children exceeds the number of adults, the excess is charged at the child rate.
- Yokosuka resident discount: Eligible visitors should present an ID showing their address at the ticket counter.
- Reservations: Accepted up to 6 months in advance by phone or via the operator’s website. Same-day tickets may be sold at the pier if seats are available.
- Recommended: Reserve by the day before, as it can get crowded.
- Parking: Use nearby paid parking (e.g., Coaska Bayside Stores parking, Baysquare Parking, or Verny Park parking).
- Accessibility (highlights):
- Elevators/escalators are available at the terminal building, but there is no elevator/escalator on the boat.
- Wheelchair access to the boat is possible with a wheelchair that has stoppers/brakes; a limited number of wheelchairs can be borrowed at the Shiioiri Terminal.
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet is available; ostomate support is not available.

Link:
- Official website: https://yokosuka-gunko.jp/
- Tourism info source page (PDF capture): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/naval-port.html
- Contact: +81-46-825-7144 (Triangle Co., Ltd.)

Tags: Yokosuka, Naval port cruise, Harbor tour, U.S. Navy, Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF), Outdoor activity, Family-friendly, Barrier-free / wheelchair-friendly

Title: Scenic Highlights on the Course — Seabreeze Hill, “View The” Deck, and the Miracle Bridge

Datetime:

Place:
- Arasaki walking course area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- **Hill Seabreeze (Shio-kaze no Oka)** is noted for a viewpoint selected as one of the “Best 50 Scenic Views in Kanagawa.”
- **“View The” Deck**: the brochure describes climbing stairs to a lookout deck with expansive water views—on clear days you may even see **Mt. Fuji** across Sagami Bay.
- **Miracle Bridge**: described as a hidden spot where a bridge girder was knocked loose by a typhoon and ended up fitting perfectly beside the stairs—creating a memorable “miracle” photo spot.
- The course map also indicates **Nagahama Beach**, **Bentenjima (Benten Island area)**, and other small landmarks along the route.

Attention:
- The Miracle Bridge and coastal lookout areas may be exposed to wind and spray; wear stable shoes.
- Keep a safe distance from wave-washed rocks, especially during high tide.

title: Ogusuyama Hiking Course (Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan)
place: Mount Ogusuyama (Ōgusuyama) area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Ogusuyama Hiking Course (Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan)

Place:
- Mount Ogusuyama (Ōgusuyama) area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- **Overview**
- Mt. Ogusuyama is known for panoramic views and is promoted as a scenic viewpoint for **Mt. Fuji** (the summit view is listed among notable viewpoints in the Kanto/Kanagawa area).
- **Hiking routes (time & difficulty)**
- **Ogusu Ashinaguchi Course**: 60 min (Difficulty: ★☆☆)
- Ogusu Ashinaguchi Bus Stop → (60 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- **Maedabashi Course**: 70 min (Difficulty: ★★☆)
- Maedabashi Bus Stop → (70 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- **Tsukayama–Abekura Course**: (1) 130 min / (2) 155 min (Difficulty: ★★★)
- (1) Anjinzuka Station / Hemi Station → (25 min) → Tsukayama Park → (45 min) → Ikegami 6-chome Bus Stop → (60 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- (2) JR Taura Station → (50 min) → Tsukayama Park → (45 min) → Ikegami 6-chome Bus Stop → (60 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- **Kinugasa Course**: 135 min (Difficulty: ★★☆)
- JR Kinugasa Station → (30 min) → Kinugasayama Park → (45 min) → Yokosuka Iris Garden → (30 min) → Ecomill → (30 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- **Shonan Village Course**: 40 min (Difficulty: ★☆☆)
- Shonan Village Center Bus Stop → (40 min) → Mt. Ogusuyama Summit
- **How to get to the nearest station or bus stop (high level)**
- Many trailheads are reached by bus from **JR Zushi Station** or **Keikyu Zushi-Hayama Station (South Exit)**.
- Some routes also connect via **Kinugasa Station**, **Yokosuka Station**, and stations on the **Keikyu Line** (e.g., Anjinzuka/Hemi).
- **Nearby tourist spots (from the brochure)**
1. **Tateishi Park** – Coastal park famous for the “Tateishi” boulder; sunsets and seasonal Mt. Fuji views are highlighted.
2. **Maeda-gawa River Trail** – Clear stream and riverside trail fed by springs from Mt. Ogusuyama.
3. **Jorakuji Temple** – Historic temple associated with Wada Yoshimori; features notable Buddhist statues (Important Cultural Properties).
4. **Yokosuka Iris Garden** – Best season: **May to late June** (about 140,000 irises). Wisteria, rhododendron, and hydrangea can also be enjoyed in their seasons.
5. **Ruins of Kinugasa Castle** – Kamakura-period castle ruins; the site used natural terrain as defense.
6. **Kinugasayama Park** – Selected among Japan’s top cherry blossom spots; about 2,000 cherry trees and a spring festival.
7. **Tsukayama Park** – Cherry blossom site that includes **Anjinzuka** (tomb related to MIURA Anjin and his wife); lively from late March to early April.
8. **Grave Monument of MIURA Anjin** – Memorial for **William Adams (MIURA Anjin)**, known for his role in early Japan–Europe exchange.

Attention:
- Watch your step: some areas may have bad footing.
- Beware of bees and snakes.
- There are **no water supply facilities** on Mt. Ogusuyama; bring your own supplies (e.g., moist towelettes).
- There is a rest area and observation tower at the summit; **operating hours vary**.
- The brochure notes that a section of the **Maeda-gawa River Trail** may be closed due to a landslide (check current conditions before you go).
- Seasonal notes:
- Cherry blossoms are especially popular **late March to early April** (Kinugasayama Park / Tsukayama Park).
- Irises peak **May to late June** (Yokosuka Iris Garden).

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Website: https://www.cocoyoko.net/
- (The brochure also introduces the “YOKOSUKA Route Museum” website via QR code.)

title: Takeyama Hiking Course (Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula) — Tourist Highlights & Access
place: Mt. Takeyama area, Yokosuka City, Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Takeyama Hiking Course (Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula) — Tourist Highlights & Access

Place:
- Mt. Takeyama area, Yokosuka City, Miura Peninsula, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- **Overview**
- Mt. Takeyama is a ~200 m mountain with lookout/rest areas and wide views (Tokyo Bay, Sagami Bay, and Mt. Fuji on clear days). Azaleas typically bloom at the summit from mid‑April to early May.
- **Tourist spots in the area (from the brochure)**
- **Mt. Takeyama (200 m):** Viewpoints, rest areas, and seasonal azaleas.
- **Takeyama Fudoin Temple:** At/near the summit; part of a pilgrimage of sacred spots on the Miura Peninsula. The brochure notes the “Hatsufudo” gathering on Jan 28.
- **Mt. Hodaiyama / Gun Battery Ruins (204 m):** Early Showa‑era gun battery remains (well‑preserved ruins).
- **Mt. Miura Fuji (183 m):** Scenic summit views toward Izu Oshima and the Boso Peninsula; the brochure notes possible Mt. Fuji views in good conditions.
- **Tsukuihama Tourist Farm:** Seasonal harvesting/picking (details below).
- **Tsukuihama Beach:** Windsurfing spot; also noted as a Windsurfing World Cup location; shops/cafes along the beach.
- **Kitashitaura Coast Daffodils:** Over 3 million daffodils bloom from mid‑December to early February (community volunteer effort).
- **#Jihangun (outdoor photo spot):** Vending‑machine‑inspired art installation; free to enjoy; located in a parking lot along Kitashitaura Kaigandori Street.
- **Tsukuihama Tourist Farm (key practical info)**
- Local information center: **046‑849‑5001** (9:00–15:00; available daily during harvesting seasons)
- Administrative office: **046‑849‑4506** (9:00–15:00; weekdays only)
- Admission time: **9:00–15:00** (admission may be limited at certain times; confirm beforehand)
- Strawberry picking: **Jan 1 – May 5** (open daily)
- Sweet potato digging: **mid‑Sep – mid‑Nov** (open Saturdays / Sundays / public holidays)
- Mandarin orange picking: **Oct 20 – Nov 30** (open daily)
- Fee: The brochure indicates **free** for harvesting-related entry info, but advises confirming harvest status/fees in advance.
- **Model hiking courses (time estimates shown in the map)**
- **Course 1 (loop): Tsukuihama Station → Tsukuihama Tourist Farm → Mt. Takeyama → Mt. Hodaiyama → Mt. Miura Fuji → Tsukuihama Station**
- Total **145 min**; segment times: 25 → 30 → 20 → 25 → 45 min (difficulty shown as ★★☆)
- **Course 2: Tsukuihama Station → Tsukuihama Tourist Farm → Mt. Takeyama → Mt. Hodaiyama → Mt. Miura Fuji → Sengenjinja Bus Stop**
- Total **115 min**; segment times: 25 → 30 → 20 → 25 → 15 min (difficulty shown as ★★☆)
- **Course 3: Ikkizuka Bus Stop → Mt. Takeyama → Mt. Hodaiyama → Mt. Miura Fuji → Tsukuihama Station**
- Total **130 min**; segment times: 40 → 20 → 25 → 45 min (difficulty shown as ★☆☆)
- **Seasonal roadside highlight**
- “Cherry Blossom Trees along Tsukendori Street”: about **350 trees** forming a “tunnel” over roughly **1.5 km**.
- **Access (as described in the brochure)**
- Train: Go directly to **Tsukuihama Station** and hike from there; or go to **Yokosuka Station** / **Yokosuka‑Chuo Station** and transfer to a bus for **Ikkizuka Bus Stop** or **Sengenjinja Bus Stop**.
- From Shinagawa:
- Keikyu Line (Ltd. Express / green display): about **60 min** to Yokosuka‑Chuo, about **80 min** to Tsukuihama.
- JR Yokosuka Line: about **70 min** to Yokosuka Station.
- Bus notes (examples shown):
- To **Ikkizuka Bus Stop**: buses from Yokosuka Station or Yokosuka‑Chuo Station; about **40 min** from Yokosuka Station / **30 min** from Yokosuka‑Chuo.
- To **Sengenjinja Bus Stop**: from **YRP Nobi Station** bus stop No. 2; about **10 min**.

Attention:
- The map labels a **“Caution: STEEP”** area near the Sengenjinja side of the route.
- Harvest schedules at Tsukuihama Tourist Farm may change with growing conditions; the brochure recommends confirming before you go.
- Public transport access relies on route buses; check the latest timetables via the Keikyu Bus ride-support page (QR shown in the brochure).

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Website (listed in the brochure):
- https://www.cocoyoko.net
- Yokosuka “Route Museum” (QR shown in the brochure; use the QR code on the map to open)
- Keikyu Bus ride-support page (QR shown in the brochure; multilingual)

Tags: hiking, Kanagawa, Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula, Takeyama, Miurafuji, Tsukuihama, seasonal flowers, farm experience, beach, public transport
