title: Umikaze Park (Yokosuka) — Seaside Lawn, BBQ, and Action Sports
place:
Umikaze Park, Heisei-cho 3-23, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi
text:
Title: Umikaze Park (Yokosuka) — Seaside Lawn, BBQ, and Action Sports

Place:
- Umikaze Park, Heisei-cho 3-23, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi

Detail:
- **What it is:** A spacious seaside park with a large lawn where you can relax and look out over Tokyo Bay—**Sarushima Island** floats right offshore.
- **BBQ by the sea:** You can enjoy barbecue while watching the ocean. A paid service, **“Umikaze BBQ,”** offers equipment rental and support (carry/clean-up and trash collection).
- **Action-sports & courts:** Areas for **skateboarding**, **3-on-3 basketball**, **mountain biking**, and **wall tennis**.
- **Family-friendly zones:**
- *Shinsui Seawall*: A waterside area designed for casual sea contact—kids and adults get excited spotting fish and crabs (collection is prohibited).
- *Water Hill*: Flowing water and a fountain/pond area that becomes a fun play spot in summer.
- *Playground Area*: Great for toddlers; toilets nearby.
- *Flowerbed Plaza*: European-style flowerbeds with seasonal blooms and a circular bed with a calmer atmosphere.
- **Scenic walk:** The “**10,000m Promenade**” is an approximately 10 km seaside walking route that continues toward the boardwalk/Kannonzaki area, with bay views (Sarushima, sea forts, Yokohama landmarks, Bay Bridge, Aqua-Line, and the Boso Peninsula).
- **History nearby:** The **Third Sea Fort** (built for Tokyo Bay defense) was constructed from 1890 (Meiji 23) over ~30 years, completed in 1921 (Taisho 10), then largely collapsed/submerged after the 1923 Great Kanto Earthquake. A large barracks structure salvaged during removal work was relocated to Umikaze Park and has been permanently exhibited as a civil engineering heritage item since **2006-03-01**.
- **Basic info:**
- Admission: **Free**
- Closed: **None**
- Access: About **15 minutes on foot** from **Keikyu Kenritsu-Daigaku Station**
- Parking: Regular **182** spaces + Large vehicles **2** spaces (paid; rates vary by time and vehicle type)
- Contact: **046-826-2899** (management office)

Attention:
- **Fountain operating limits (summer):** Due to summer electricity-saving measures, the fountain runs **only on weekends and holidays from July to September**.
- **BBQ rules:** Use a grill/stove (no open flame on the grass). Do not barbecue on paths or planted areas. Take all trash home (including ash/charcoal), and do not wash greasy grates/plates in drains.
- **Nature protection:** **Collecting living creatures is prohibited** in the waterside area.
- **Drones:** **Drone use is not permitted** in the park.
- **Barrier-free notes:** Slopes are available for entrance steps; accessible toilets and diaper-changing sheets exist, and there are designated parking spaces (4). Elevators/escalators and wheelchair rental are not available.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page (spot page): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/umikaze-park.html
- Official park site: https://www.kanagawaparks.com/umikaze/
- Umikaze BBQ (service page): https://digiq.jp/portal/experience/73735/0

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, seaside park, Sarushima view, BBQ, skatepark, 3-on-3 basketball, mountain bike course, family-friendly, 10,000m promenade, barrier-free

Title: Kurihama Flower Park (Kurihama Hananokuni)

Place:

Detail:
- Kurihama Flower Park is a flower-themed park where visitors can enjoy lush greenery and seasonal blooms.
- Best seasons:
- Spring: poppies
- Autumn: cosmos
- The Herb Garden is especially popular from May to July for lavender and other aromatic herbs.
- There is a free footbath called **“Yuttari (湯足里)”**, where the water is blended with seasonal herbs.
- Family-friendly highlights include an adventure area with a **Godzilla slide** and multiple playgrounds.
- Admission is free (some facilities may charge additional fees).

Attention:
- **No closing day** for the park itself, but individual facilities may have their own business hours/holidays.
- **Parking fees apply** even though admission is free.
- **Accessibility (barrier-free) notes:**
- No elevators or escalators.
- Ramps/step-free measures at entrances: available.
- Accessible toilets: available (no ostomate toilets).
- Wheelchair rental: not available.
- Disabled parking: available (8 spaces).
- Wheelchair users can generally access the park via the **Flower Train**, but if you get off mid-route, some steep slopes may be difficult to manage alone.
- **Drones and similar devices are not permitted** inside the park.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism spot page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/hananokuni.html
- Official park site: http://www.kanagawaparks.com/kurihama-perry/

place: 18-1 Abekura, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0033, Japan (Kinugasa area)
text:
Title: Yokosuka Iris Garden (Shobu-en / しょうぶ園)

Datetime:
- Best bloom: late May to late June (Hanashobu / Japanese irises)

Place:
- 18-1 Abekura, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0033, Japan (Kinugasa area)

Detail:
- One of Japan’s largest iris gardens: about 412 varieties and 140,000 Japanese iris plants spread across ~3.8 hectares.
- Besides irises, the park also features a wisteria garden (11 varieties, ~250 wisteria) and areas such as a rhododendron garden, so visitors can enjoy seasonal flowers throughout the year.
- Visitor Center facilities include: a restaurant seating about 100, an exhibition room, and a rest area where you can bring your own bento.
- Access (public transport):
- From JR Kinugasa Station: “Shobu-en Loop” bus (~10 min) to “Shobu-en” stop (2–3 buses/hour).
- From JR Kinugasa Station: bus toward Yokosuka Station (via Ikegami) or toward Shioiri Station (~5 min) → get off at “Ikegami Junior High School” → walk ~15 min.
- From Keikyu Shioiri Station: bus toward Kinugasa Station (via Ikegami) (~15 min) → “Ikegami Junior High School” → walk ~15 min.

Attention:
- Admission is free in general, but during the iris season (Apr–Jun) there is an entrance fee: Adults ¥320; Elementary/Junior High students ¥100.
- Parking: 90 standard cars + 3 large vehicles.
- Standard car: ¥320 for the first hour, then ¥150 per additional 30 minutes
- Large vehicle: ¥2,100 per visit
- Drones and similar devices are not allowed inside the park.
- Accessibility (barrier-free):
- Mostly wheelchair-accessible within the garden; wheelchair-accessible toilet available; wheelchair rental available.
- No ostomate toilet; no adult “universal sheet.”
- Accessible parking spaces available (2 spaces).
- Baby diaper-changing sheet is available for children; while a dedicated changing sheet may not be provided in all areas, a bed for diaper changing is available.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/iris-park.html
- http://www.ryokukazouen.jp/iris/  (official site)
- Tel (management office): +81-46-853-3688

- Visitors can enjoy a wide variety of shops, including:

- Popular local restaurants
- Sweets and dessert shops
- Yokosuka souvenirs
- The venue encourages visitors to experience the renewed Yokosuka Port Market and explore local food culture.

Attention:

- Barrier-free notes:

- Accessible parking for people with disabilities: available (1 space)

title: Yokosuka Modern Heritage Museum Thibaudier Residence
datetime: Regular hours: 09:00–17:00 (open daily; no regular closing day).
place:
Address: 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City (inside Verny Park), Kanagawa, Japan.
Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi.
Access: ~5 minutes on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; ~5 minutes on foot from Keikyu Shioiri Station.
text:
Title: Yokosuka Modern Heritage Museum Thibaudier Residence

Datetime:
- Regular hours: 09:00–17:00 (open daily; no regular closing day).

Place:
- Address: 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City (inside Verny Park), Kanagawa, Japan.
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi.
- Access: ~5 minutes on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; ~5 minutes on foot from Keikyu Shioiri Station.

Detail:
- A reconstructed Western-style residence originally built around 1869 as official housing for Jules César Claude Thibaudier, a French engineer (deputy head) at the Yokosuka Ironworks—considered one of the oldest Western-style buildings of its class on Honshu.
- Inside, visitors can see relocated original structural elements such as the wooden-frame brick wall and truss components, alongside exhibits introducing Yokosuka’s modernization history.
- The facility also serves as a hub for the “Yokosuka Route Museum,” which connects citywide historical, cultural, and nature “satellite” spots through themed routes.
- Optional theater experience: A guided 3D-CG, hands-on movie experience (approx. 15 minutes) with rotating themes (e.g., “Black Ships Arrival”).

Attention:
- Admission: Free (some paid content available).
- Theater fee: 200 JPY; free for high school students and younger. Screenings are typically twice per hour (at :00 and :30); reservations recommended if seats are limited.
- Barrier-free notes: No elevator or escalator; ramp measures for entrance steps are available; wheelchair-accessible toilet is available; wheelchair rental is not available.

Link:
- Official site: http://thibaudier-yokosuka.com/
- Reservation (theater): https://airrsv.net/yokosuka-thibaudier/calendar
- Source page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/Thibaudier.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Museum, Modernization history, Western-style architecture, Verny Park, Route Museum, Family-friendly, Barrier-free (partial)

title: Museum Haus Kasuya (Kasuya-no-Mori Museum of Contemporary Art)
place: 7-12-13 Hirasaku, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0032, Japan (Kinugasa area)
text:
Title: Museum Haus Kasuya (Kasuya-no-Mori Museum of Contemporary Art)

Place:
- 7-12-13 Hirasaku, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0032, Japan (Kinugasa area)

Detail:
- A privately run contemporary art museum founded by the contemporary artist Kanji Wakae.
- The museum sits on roughly 6,600 m² of grounds with seasonal flowers, plus a bamboo grove walking path where Rakan statues and artworks are scattered.
- Inside the museum, there is a tea lounge surrounded by bamboo. Enjoy a relaxing break while looking out at the greenery after viewing the exhibitions.
- Opened in April 1994 and focuses mainly on solo exhibitions by active artists. It also hosts events such as seminars, tea gatherings, symposiums, and concerts.
- **Hours:** 10:00–17:30 (last entry 17:00)
- **Closed:** Monday–Wednesday (except during weeks of exhibition changeovers)
- **Admission:** Adults ¥800 / Students ¥600 / Elementary school children ¥400
- **Parking:** 10 spaces, free
- **Access:**
- From Keikyu Shioiri Station: take a bus bound for Kinugasa Station (~15 min), get off at “Kanaya,” then walk ~7 min.
- From JR Kinugasa Station: ~15 min on foot.

Attention:
- Lunch service is currently suspended due to COVID-19-related measures, but beverages such as coffee and tea are still available.
- The galleries are wheelchair-accessible, but there are stairs before the entrance; staff can assist visitors at this section.
- Accessibility notes: wheelchair-accessible restroom available; wheelchair rental available. (No elevator or escalator.)

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kasuya.html
- Official site: http://www.museum-haus-kasuya.com/

Tags: yokosuka, kinugasa, museum, contemporary-art, bamboo-grove, garden, tea-lounge, accessibility

title: Perry Park (Kurihama, Yokosuka) — Landing Site of Commodore Matthew C. Perry
place:
Perry Park (Perry Kōen), Kurihama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
Address: 7-14 Kurihama, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0831
text:
Title: Perry Park (Kurihama, Yokosuka) — Landing Site of Commodore Matthew C. Perry

Place:
- Perry Park (Perry Kōen), Kurihama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address: 7-14 Kurihama, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0831

Detail:
- **Why it’s worth visiting:** Perry Park marks the moment Japan’s “opening to the world” accelerated. Inside the park stands the **Perry Landing Monument**, built to commemorate Commodore **Matthew Calbraith Perry** landing at Kurihama Beach on July 14, 1853 and delivering the U.S. President’s letter requesting Japan to open the country.
- **What to see:**
- **Perry Landing Monument** (the monument’s inscription is attributed to the calligraphy of **Hirobumi Ito**).
- **Perry Memorial Museum** (inside the park): exhibits historical materials and models related to Perry’s arrival.
- **Jōkisen Monument**: a witty poem/pun comparing the shock of “four cups of tea that keep you awake” with the shock of “four steamships arriving,” capturing how startling the “Black Ships” appeared to people at the time.
- **Scenery note:** The coastline once had a well-known beach; later land reclamation and industrial development changed the shoreline. From the remaining sandy area, you can still see the **Tokyo Wan Ferry** route and large industrial structures offshore.

Attention:
- **Admission:** Free.
- **Access (public transport):** From **Keikyū Kurihama Station**, take a bus bound for **Nobi Kaigan** (~10 minutes) and get off at **“Perry Kinenhi”** bus stop.
- **Parking:** None.
- **Accessibility (summary):** No elevator/escalator; slope measures at the entrance are available, but wheelchair-accessible toilets and several other barrier-free facilities are not available.
- **Rules:** Use of drones and similar devices is **not permitted** in the park.
- **Contact:** Perry Memorial Museum +81-46-834-7531

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/perry-park.html
- Official park site: http://www.kanagawaparks.com/kurihama-perry/perry/

Tags: Yokosuka, Kurihama, Perry Park, Japanese history, Black Ships, Monument, Museum, Waterfront walk

title: Perry Commemorative Museum (Perry Memorial Museum), Kurihama, Yokosuka
place:
Perry Commemorative Museum
7-14 Kurihama, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0831, Japan (Kurihama area)
text:
Title: Perry Commemorative Museum (Perry Memorial Museum), Kurihama, Yokosuka

Place:
- Perry Commemorative Museum
- 7-14 Kurihama, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0831, Japan (Kurihama area)

Detail:
- A small museum dedicated to Commodore Perry’s arrival in Japan. Exhibits include historical materials and models related to Perry’s expedition, as well as illustrated scrolls and “kawaraban” news sheets that convey how people at the time reacted with surprise and anxiety. The museum aims to preserve and communicate the historical significance of the event for future generations.
- Admission: Free
- Hours: 09:00–16:30
- Closed: Mondays (or the following day if Monday is a public holiday), and during the year-end/New Year holidays
- Parking: None
- Access: From Keikyu Kurihama Station or JR Kurihama Station, take the “Kurihama Junkan” bus (~10 min) and get off at “Perry Kinenhi” (Perry Memorial) bus stop.

Attention:
- No on-site parking.
- Accessibility is limited: no elevator/escalator; an entrance ramp/slope is available. Wheelchair users can reach the 1st-floor exhibition room, but other accessibility facilities (wheelchair-accessible toilet, wheelchair rental, etc.) are not available.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/perry.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/fc00000442.html

title: Recycle Plaza “Aicle” Facility Tour (Yokosuka City)
place: Recycle Plaza Aicle, 5-2931 Uragocho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Oppama / Taura area)
text:
Title: Recycle Plaza “Aicle” Facility Tour (Yokosuka City)

Place:
- Recycle Plaza Aicle, 5-2931 Uragocho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Oppama / Taura area)

Detail:
- A staff-led guided tour helps visitors understand the facility’s role. After watching a short video that summarizes Aicle and the recycling flow, you walk along the viewing corridor while staff explains the exhibit corner, the platform, the storage pit, sorting equipment, and other plant facilities. You can learn practical waste separation and recycling tips.
- A recycling-themed event, the “Aicle Fair,” is held once a year.
- Opening hours: 08:30–17:00.
- Guided tour times (when open): Morning 10:00–11:30; Afternoon 14:00–15:30. The tour typically takes about 1.5 hours including the video (the duration can be adjusted).
- Self-guided visit: 08:30–17:00 on open days.
- Plant operating windows (Mon–Fri): 08:25–09:45, 10:05–11:25, 12:25–13:50, 14:15–15:40.
- Admission: Free.
- Parking: Free (24 standard cars, available 08:30–17:00). For large buses, consult the facility when booking.

Attention:
- Reservations are required for the guided tour: book by phone in advance (+81-46-866-1196). You may also be asked to submit a “Recycle Plaza Tour Application Form” (text or PDF) to the 1F administration office by the day of your visit (FAX/email/mail accepted).
- Closed days: Mondays (if Monday is a public holiday, the following day and the day after), the day after a public holiday (shifted if it falls on Sat/Sun), year-end/new year (Dec 29–Jan 3), plus temporary closures.
- Accessibility: elevator available; step-free entrance measures; wheelchair-accessible toilet and wheelchair rental available; diaper-changing sheet available; accessible parking (2 spaces).

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourism Info page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/aicle.html
- Official Yokosuka City page: https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/4170/aicle/index.html

title: Verny Park (ヴェルニー公園) — French-style waterfront park in Yokosuka
place:
Verny Park, 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa 238-0042, Japan
Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi (Yokosuka waterfront)
text:
Title: Verny Park (ヴェルニー公園) — French-style waterfront park in Yokosuka

Place:
- Verny Park, 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa 238-0042, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi (Yokosuka waterfront)

Detail:
- Overview:
- A waterfront park redesigned in a **French garden style**, completed at the end of FY2001 (Heisei 13). It was previously known locally as “Rinkai Park.”
- The park includes **French-style flowerbeds, fountains, and Western-style gazebos**, plus busts of **François Léonce Verny** and **Tadayoshi Oguri**.
- A rose garden features **about 130 varieties and about 1,300 rose bushes**, mainly French cultivars.
- Along the sea, a **boardwalk** offers breezy walking and jogging.
- Views:
- You can look over Yokosuka’s main port and often see **moored naval vessels**.
- From the park: **U.S. Navy base on the right**, **JMSDF District HQ on the left**.
- Visitor basics:
- Admission: **Free**
- Opening hours: **No fixed hours**
- Access:
- Keikyu **Shioiri Station**: ~5 minutes on foot
- JR **Yokosuka Station**: ~1 minute on foot
- Parking:
- Verny Park parking lot: **10 standard cars** (incl. 1 accessible space) and **6 large buses** (paid; buses require reservation)
- Standard cars: **420 JPY / hour**, then **210 JPY / 30 minutes**; 24-hour entry/exit
- Large vehicles: **2,100 JPY per visit**; usable 8:30–17:30
- On-site working space:
- **CORSAIRE Working Space**: 11:00–17:00 (last entry 16:00)
- Closed: Mondays, year-end and New Year holidays
- Reservations: by phone, up to 3 months in advance (the user must make the reservation)

Attention:
- Drones (and similar devices) are **not permitted** inside the park.
- Accessibility:
- Entrance step-free measures (including slopes): available
- Wheelchair-accessible restroom: available
- No elevator / escalator; no wheelchair rental
- Accessible parking spaces: available (2)
- Note: Some historical sites (e.g., the dry dock) may only be viewable from outside restricted areas.

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/verny-park.html
- Official park site: https://www.kanagawaparks.com/verny/

title: Verny Commemorative Museum (Verny Kinenkan), Yokosuka
place:
Verny Commemorative Museum, Verny Park area, Yokosuka (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi)
Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
Access: 1 minute on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; about 10 minutes on foot from Keikyu “Shioiri” Station
text:
Title: Verny Commemorative Museum (Verny Kinenkan), Yokosuka

Place:
- Verny Commemorative Museum, Verny Park area, Yokosuka (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi)
- Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
- Access: 1 minute on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; about 10 minutes on foot from Keikyu “Shioiri” Station

Detail:
- The Verny Commemorative Museum was built to preserve and share the achievements of the French engineer François Léonce Verny, who helped create the Yokosuka Iron Works—often described as a starting point of Japan’s modernization.
- The museum sits in a corner of Verny Park, looking across the water toward the former iron works site (now the U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base).
- The exterior design features a steep roof and stone walls inspired by traditional homes in Brittany, France (Verny’s home region).
- Highlights inside include two steam hammers installed at the Yokosuka Iron Works under Verny’s direction. They are considered the oldest surviving steam hammers in Japan and are designated as Important Cultural Properties.
- Both steam hammers were manufactured in 1865, imported from the Netherlands the following year, and reportedly operated for more than 100 years making parts such as ship components.
- Additional exhibits include:
- A 1/10 scale model recreating the 3-ton steam hammer as it appeared during its final operation period
- A hands-on device to experience Pascal’s principle
- Video exhibits recreating the late-Edo/Meiji-era Yokosuka Iron Works with 3D computer graphics
- Video programs introducing the steam hammers and Yokosuka’s modern industrial heritage
- Reference books, and sales of original goods and selected history-related publications

Attention:
- Admission: Free
- Hours: 09:00–17:00
- Closed: Mondays (if Monday is a public holiday, closed the following day) and during the year-end/New Year period
- Parking: None
- Accessibility (summary):
- No elevator/escalator; no entrance ramp/slope measures indicated
- Wheelchair rental: Available
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet / ostomate toilet: Not available
- Tactile guiding blocks: Available
- If you need step-free access, check the published barrier-free route information before visiting

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/verny.html
- Official site: https://www.museum.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/satellite-facilities/verney

Tags: yokosuka, museum, industrial-heritage, history, verny, steam-hammer, verny-park, free-admission

title: Shikkama Tunnels (JR Taura Station)
place: JR Taura Station (Yokosuka Line), Taura-cho 1-6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (inside the station premises)
text:
Title: Shikkama Tunnels (JR Taura Station)

Place:
- JR Taura Station (Yokosuka Line), Taura-cho 1-6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (inside the station premises)

Detail:
- JR Taura Station is famous for its unusually short platform (about 200 m). With 11-car trains, some cars stop inside a tunnel, so certain doors do not open.
- On the Yokosuka Station side of JR Taura Station, three adjacent tunnels from three eras can be seen from the station overpass: the oldest (down line) completed in 1889 (Meiji era), a brick-built tunnel added in 1924 (Taisho era) for double-tracking, and the largest tunnel built in 1943 (Showa era) for wartime military freight.
- The area name is historically “Shikkama” (literally “lost sickle”), and the tunnel name is said to use the homophone “Shikkama” written as “Shikkama / Shikkama (Seven Kettles)” to avoid the unlucky association of “losing a boiler (kama)” for steam locomotives.

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility support is very limited (e.g., no elevators/escalators; wheelchair-accessible toilet and other related facilities are not available).
- When boarding/alighting, follow station guidance because some doors may remain closed due to the short platform.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/taura-st.html

Tags: yokosuka, taura, railway, tunnel, history, architecture, meiji, taisho, showa, trainspotting

title: Mt. Miurafuji (Miura Fuji) — Panoramic View Hike in Yokosuka
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area)
Access: About 60 minutes on foot from Keikyu Nagasawa Station
Parking: None
Contact: Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office (+81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00)
text:
Title: Mt. Miurafuji (Miura Fuji) — Panoramic View Hike in Yokosuka

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area)
- Access: About 60 minutes on foot from Keikyu Nagasawa Station
- Parking: None
- Contact: Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office (+81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00)

Detail:
- Mt. Miurafuji is not a very high mountain, but the summit offers wide-open views. On clear days, you can see from Sagami Bay all the way to Tokyo Bay, and even Izu Oshima and the Boso Peninsula.
- With good luck, you may also spot Mt. Fuji appearing grandly above Mt. Takeyama.
- From the summit area, you can overlook the full view of “Hikari-no-Oka” at YRP (Yokosuka Research Park), a cluster of mobile communications R&D institutes.
- A hiking route is maintained that links Tsukuihama → Mt. Miurafuji → Hodaiyama → Mt. Takeyama.
- Cultural note: A Sengen Shrine (Oku-miya) is enshrined at the summit, with a stone monument carved “Sengen Shrine Oku-miya.” Historically, fishermen used Mt. Miurafuji and Mt. Takeyama as landmarks to locate fishing grounds and identify the direction back to port, connecting the mountain to faith in big catches and maritime safety.

Attention:
- Water facilities are available at the Mt. Takeyama summit toilet (not necessarily at Mt. Miurafuji itself).
- No parking is available—public transportation is recommended.
- Accessibility: The site is not barrier-free (no elevators/escalators/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing or universal sheet; no accessible parking; no guiding blocks).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/miurafuzi.html

Tags: #Yokosuka #Kanagawa #MiuraPeninsula #Hiking #Trail #ScenicView #MtMiurafuji #Nature #SengenShrine #YRP

title: Memorial Ship MIKASA (One of the “World’s Three Great Memorial Ships”)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:06 (JST) — captured from Yokosuka City Tourism Information page timestamp
place:
Memorial Ship MIKASA (inside Mikasa Park)
82-19 Inaoka-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0003, Japan (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area)
text:
Title: Memorial Ship MIKASA (One of the “World’s Three Great Memorial Ships”)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:06 (JST) — captured from Yokosuka City Tourism Information page timestamp

Place:
- Memorial Ship MIKASA (inside Mikasa Park)
- 82-19 Inaoka-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0003, Japan (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area)

Detail:
- **Why it’s special:** Mikasa is a steel battleship built in **1902** in the United Kingdom and is known as the **flagship of Japan’s Combined Fleet** under Admiral **Heihachiro Togo** during the **Russo-Japanese War**. It is described as the **world’s oldest surviving steel battleship** and is recognized as a component cultural property of **Japan Heritage**.
- **Historical highlights:** After retiring from service (1923), Mikasa was preserved in Yokosuka as a memorial ship (1926). Following WWII, parts such as the guns, masts, and bridge were removed by order of the occupation forces, but the ship was later restored to its current form in **1961** with donations and support including from the U.S. Navy.
- **What to see onboard:** Exhibits include Imperial Japanese Navy uniforms/equipment, Russo-Japanese War materials, and restored rooms (e.g., the Commander-in-Chief’s room, Chief of Staff room, Captain’s room). At the conning tower, footprints mark the spot where Admiral Togo is said to have stood for five hours during the Battle of the Sea of Japan.
- **Key ship specs (quick facts):** Displacement 15,140 tons; length 132 m; beam 23 m; speed 18 knots; crew 860; main guns 4 × 30 cm; secondary 14 × 15 cm; 20 × 8 cm; 4 × 45 cm torpedo tubes.
- **Admission:** 600 JPY (adults), 300 JPY (high school students), free (elementary & junior high students).
- **Opening hours:**
- Apr–Sep: 09:00–17:30
- Mar & Oct: 09:00–17:00
- Nov–Feb: 09:00–16:30
- **Closed:** Dec 28–31
- **Access:**
- From Keikyu **Yokosuka-Chuo Station**: ~15 min on foot, or take the Mikasa loop bus and get off at “Mikasa Park.”
- From JR **Yokosuka Station**: take a bus toward Yokosuka-Chuo area (~10 min), get off at “Otaki-cho,” then ~7 min walk.
- By car: from Yokohama-Yokosuka Road **Yokosuka IC**, follow Prefectural Route 28 to Route 16, then turn left at the Mikasa Park entrance.
- **Parking (Mikasa Park parking, 42 spaces):** 410 JPY up to 1 hour; +210 JPY per 30 minutes up to 2 hours; after 2 hours, 830 JPY plus +100 JPY per additional hour (up to 1 hour increments).

Attention:
- **Accessibility notes (important):**
- No elevator / no escalator.
- Step-free entry measures (including a slope/ramp) are available.
- Wheelchair rental is available, but **wheelchair users must enter via the forward entrance on the middle deck (1F)** and **cannot move to the upper deck (2F)**.
- Wheelchair-accessible toilets are **not available** (also no ostomate-ready toilets, no baby diaper-changing sheet, and no adult universal changing sheet).
- **Plan around closures:** The ship is **closed Dec 28–31**, so avoid year-end dates.
- **Crowd/comfort tip:** Winter hours end earlier (16:30), so arrive with enough time if visiting Nov–Feb.

Link:
- Yokosuka City Tourism Info: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/mikasa.html
- Official site: http://www.kinenkan-mikasa.or.jp/

Tags: #Yokosuka, #MemorialShipMikasa, #MikasaPark, #HistoricShip, #NavalHistory, #RussoJapaneseWar, #HeihachiroTogo, #Museum, #Kanagawa, #JapanHeritage, #Accessibility

text:
Title: Jyusan Pass (十三峠 / Jyusan Pass)

Datetime:
- Historical context: 1720 (Kyōhō 5) onward, when travel between Edo and Uraga increased; later referenced in 1812; associated with late-Edo ukiyo-e artist Utagawa Hiroshige.
- Source page capture timestamp: 2025-12-26 20:35 (as shown in the report).

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan — Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area.
- Along the former “East Uraga Road” (Higashi no Uraga-michi), near Ota-zaka by Chōzen-ji, continuing on the ridge toward Anjin-zuka.

Detail:
- A historically steep and demanding mountain path on the “East Uraga Road,” said to have been the biggest bottleneck on the Uraga route for travelers and local villagers.
- Name origin traditions include: “the 13th pass from Hodogaya,” or being connected to a place of worship related to the “Thirteen Buddhas,” among other local theories.
- Scenic viewpoint: on clear days, you can see as far as Yokohama Landmark Tower, Nagaura Bay, and the factory groups of the Chiba coastal industrial zone.
- Cultural note: Hiroshige is said to have been struck by the panoramic view here and reportedly depicted it in his travel sketch diary (“Hiroshige Busō Meisho Tabi Enikki”).

Attention:
- Parking: none.
- Barrier-free facilities are not available (no elevators/escalators/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilet; no ostomate toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing or universal seat; no designated accessible parking; no guidance blocks).
- Although the old road is now a paved road open to cars, the area is historically steep—wear appropriate shoes and be cautious in bad weather.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/13touge.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, viewpoint, hiking, historic-road, uraga-road, edo-period, hiroshige, taura

title: Jyunisho Shrine (十二所神社)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:37 (page capture timestamp shown in the source)
place:
1-21-26 Ashina, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama (West Coast area of Yokosuka)
text:
Title: Jyunisho Shrine (十二所神社)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:37 (page capture timestamp shown in the source)

Place:
- 1-21-26 Ashina, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama (West Coast area of Yokosuka)

Detail:
- An old shrine historically known as “Miura Juniten Myojin,” said to have been venerated as a guardian shrine of Ashina Castle.
- Appears in the *Azuma Kagami* as one of the shrines associated with Minamoto no Yoritomo’s prayers for the safe childbirth of his wife, Hojo Masako.
- In the precincts, there is an “Obitoke (belt-untying) Koyasu Jizo,” said to have been made from the ashes of a goma fire lit by Kobo Daishi; it is believed to help with safe childbirth and fertility.
- Historical notes include: unknown founding date; local traditions linking it to a nearby residence site; archaeological finds of roof tiles suggesting an established settlement by the late Heian period.
- Access: From Keikyu Zushi-Hayama Station, take a bus toward Nagai (about 25 minutes), get off at “Ashina” bus stop, then walk about 15 minutes.

Attention:
- No parking available.
- Limited barrier-free facilities (no elevator/escalator/slope measures; no wheelchair-accessible toilet, etc.).
- Wheelchairs can reach the bottom of the stone steps on the approach, but the stairs may limit further access.
- Contact: Yokosuka Tourist Information Center (Tel: +81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/zyunisho-z.html

title: Chiyogasaki Gun Battery Site (Chiyogasaki Hōdai-ato)
place: 6-5-1 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area)
text:
Title: Chiyogasaki Gun Battery Site (Chiyogasaki Hōdai-ato)

Datetime:
- Accessed: 2025-12-26 (Local time in source: 20:38)

Place:
- 6-5-1 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area)

Detail:
- Chiyogasaki Gun Battery is a Western-style coastal artillery fort built by the Imperial Japanese Army between 1892 and 1895, next to the earlier “Hironeyama Daiba” (Hironeyama Battery) remains that were constructed by the Aizu Domain in the late Edo period.
- The site sits on a hill (about 65 m above sea level) with three north–south gun emplacements. Each emplacement originally held two howitzers.
- The emplacements are bowl-shaped, and underground you can still see brick-walled, concrete-ceilinged protected rooms (bombproof shelters) and ammunition magazines.
- Surviving features include a shell-hoist shaft used to supply shells to the guns and an internal water supply/drainage system.
- Because it preserves its original construction well and is important for understanding modern Japanese military and fortification technology, the site was designated a National Historic Site in 2015. It is also recognized as a component cultural asset of Japan Heritage.

Attention:
- Opening days: Saturdays, Sundays, and Japanese public holidays (closed Dec 29–Jan 3).
- Opening hours:
- Oct–Feb: 09:30–15:30 (last entry 15:00)
- Mar–Sep: 09:30–16:30 (last entry 16:00)
- Temporary closure may occur during severe weather (heavy rain, flooding, strong winds), typhoons, snowfall, or other unsafe conditions.
- No vehicles (including bicycles and motorbikes) may enter or park inside the site. Use nearby parking areas (including paid parking) and walk in.
- Accessibility: Barrier-free facilities are not provided (e.g., no elevator/escalator, no step-free entrance measures, and no wheelchair-accessible restroom).

title: Oryo’s Tomb (Grave of Ryoma Sakamoto’s Wife)
place: Shingyoji Temple (信楽寺), 3-29-1 Otsu-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Otsu area)
text:
Title: Oryo’s Tomb (Grave of Ryoma Sakamoto’s Wife)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:26 (JST)  *(page capture timestamp)*

Place:
- Shingyoji Temple (信楽寺), 3-29-1 Otsu-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Otsu area)

Detail:
- This spot is the grave of Oryo (also known as Ryoko), the wife of Ryoma Sakamoto, who is widely remembered for saving him during the Teradaya Incident.
- After Ryoma’s death, she later remarried in Yokosuka and lived under the name “Nishimura Tsuru,” first in Otsu and then in Yonegahama.
- She spent the last 33 years of her life in Yokosuka, and her grave is now located at Shingyoji Temple in Otsu.
- Every autumn, memorial events such as a graveside service are held as the “Oryo-san Festival” to honor her.

Attention:
- No parking is available on-site.
- The access route from Keikyu Otsu Station includes stairs, and the site is not barrier-free (no elevator/escalator, no ramps, no accessible toilets, no wheelchair rental).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/oryou.html
- Contact (Yokosuka Tourist Information Office): +81-46-822-8301 (09:30–17:00)

- Events:
- “Tsukayama Park Sakura Festival” is typically held from late March to early April.
- A cherry-viewing gathering related to Miura Anjin (“Miura Anjin Festival – Kan’ōkai”) is also held.
- The park is selected as one of the “Kanagawa Scenic Views 50.”
- Historical highlight: the graves of Miura Anjin (William Adams) and his wife are located here. Adams served Tokugawa Ieyasu and introduced Western technologies such as gunnery, shipbuilding, and navigation.

Attention:

- Drone use is not permitted inside the park.

- Wheelchair-accessible toilet: available
- Wheelchair rental: available

title: Mt. Ogusuyama (Ogusuyama)

place: Yokosuka City, Miura Peninsula (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area), Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Mt. Ogusuyama (Ogusuyama)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:36 (JST) — page capture timestamp shown in the report

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Miura Peninsula (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area), Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- Mt. Ogusuyama is the highest peak on the Miura Peninsula (241 m).
- The east–west ridgeline around the mountain is protected as a scenic preservation area, and the nature remains rich.
- From the summit plaza, you can enjoy views of Mt. Fuji and Tokyo Bay.
- There are five popular hiking courses around Mt. Ogusuyama, each with its own character. You can also enjoy seasonal flowers such as cherry blossoms, plum blossoms, and wildflowers.

Attention:
- Parking: none.
- Contact (Yokosuka Tourist Information Center): +81-46-822-8301 (9:30–17:00). Shortened hours on Dec 30 (9:30–15:00). Closed Dec 31–Jan 3.
- IMPORTANT: The summit rest area (View House), toilets, and observation tower are currently unavailable.
- Toilets are available at “Ogusu-daira” (about a 5-minute walk from the summit).
- Please avoid bringing vehicles onto the hiking trails: some sections are narrow and unpaved, and it can be dangerous for both vehicles and hikers.
- Accessibility: no elevators/escalators/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilets, rentals, or other listed barrier-free facilities.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/oogusuyama.html

title: Tenjinjima Marine Biological Garden (Tenjinjima Rinkai Shizen Kyoikuen)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:39 JST (timestamp shown on the source page)
place: Tenjinjima Marine Biological Garden, 3-7-3 Sajima, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 240-0103, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area; west coast of the Miura Peninsula facing Sagami Bay)
text:
Title: Tenjinjima Marine Biological Garden (Tenjinjima Rinkai Shizen Kyoikuen)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:39 JST (timestamp shown on the source page)

Place:
- Tenjinjima Marine Biological Garden, 3-7-3 Sajima, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 240-0103, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area; west coast of the Miura Peninsula facing Sagami Bay)

Detail:
- Tenjinjima Marine Biological Garden is located on the west coast of the Miura Peninsula, facing Sagami Bay. It preserves one of the peninsula’s few remaining natural coastlines, with many coastal plants and shore animals living in the park.
- The Tenjinjima–Kasajima area and surrounding waters (about 54 hectares) are known as the northern limit of the coastal plant *Hama-omoto* (*Hamayuu*), which blooms in summer. Because of both its botanical value and scenic landscape, the area is designated by Kanagawa Prefecture as a Natural Monument and a Place of Scenic Beauty.
- The visitor center exhibits specimens and photos of coastal plants, insects, and fish found around Tenjinjima, as well as fishing tools from Sajima.

Attention:
- Admission: Free.
- Opening hours:
- Apr–Sep: 09:00–17:00
- Oct–Mar: 09:00–16:30
- Closed: Mondays (or the following day if Monday is a national holiday) and during the year-end/New Year period.
- Parking: 15 standard cars (free).
- Accessibility (summary): Elevator and entrance slope available; wheelchair-accessible toilet and wheelchair rental available. (Escalator, ostomate toilet, baby diaper-changing sheet, and adult changing “universal sheet” are not available; dedicated disabled parking is not available.)

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/tenzin-park.html
- https://www.museum.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/information/access/tenjinjima

title: Koyasu Village (Satoyama hamlet in Yokosuka)
place: Koyasu Village, Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Koyasu Village (Satoyama hamlet in Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:22 JST

Place:
- Koyasu Village, Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- Koyasu is a small hamlet of a little over 20 households, said to have been founded by ancestors of the Karube family. Residents traditionally worked in farming and (in the past) charcoal-making.
- The area preserves a beautiful satoyama landscape where you can enjoy seasonal wildflowers. Along the road, you may find unattended stands selling local vegetables, fruit, and flowers.
- By climbing the prefectural road slope, you reach Shonan International Village. On clear days, you can enjoy wide views from the Shonan coast to the Izu Peninsula and Mt. Fuji.
- Around the Shonan International Village Center, azaleas are in full bloom from late April to early May.
- Nearby/related spots include Junisho Shrine, Awashima Shrine, Akiya–Tateishi Coast, and the “Koyasui Stone.”

Attention:
- Parking: none. Plan to arrive by public transport and walk.
- Access (bus + walk):
- From JR Zushi Station or Keikyu Zushi-Hayama Station: take a bus bound for Yokosuka Shimin Byoin / Nagai / Sajima Marina Iriguchi / Denryoku Chuo Kenkyujo, get off at “Kuruwa,” then walk.
- From Keikyu Shioiri Station: take a bus to “Shonan International Village Center,” get off at the final stop, then walk about 20 minutes.
- Accessibility: limited (no elevator/escalator; wheelchair-friendly toilet and other accessible facilities are not available). Expect slopes/uneven paths and wear comfortable shoes.
- Best viewing season for azaleas: late April to early May (check bloom timing before visiting).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/koyasu-village.html
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Office (9:30–17:00): +81-46-822-8301

Tags: Yokosuka, Akiya, Satoyama, Scenic viewpoint, Seasonal flowers, Azaleas, Hiking / walking, Local produce stands, Shonan International Village

title: Koumi-ishi Stone (子産石)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:19 (JST) — retrieved from Yokosuka City tourism information page
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area)
Near the “Koumi-ishi (子産石)” bus stop
text:
Title: Koumi-ishi Stone (子産石)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:19 (JST) — retrieved from Yokosuka City tourism information page

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area)
- Near the “Koumi-ishi (子産石)” bus stop

Detail:
- Koumi-ishi (literally “child-bearing stone”) is a stone long revered as a symbol of fertility and safe childbirth.
- A historical record known as *Miura Kokyuroku* mentions a “Koumi-ishi” at Kuruwa-no-hama, describing how the stone “produces” or “splits off” stones over the years—hence the name.
- Local traditions say that women hoping to conceive would rub the stone and then rub their abdomen with the same hand, and that pregnant women may rub their belly with the stone to pray for an easy delivery.
- A representative Koumi-ishi stone (about 1 meter in diameter) located near the bus stop has been designated as a municipal cultural asset (citizen cultural heritage).

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility: the site listing indicates no elevator/escalator, no ramps/step-free entrance measures, and no wheelchair-accessible toilets or other universal facilities. Plan accordingly, especially if visiting with a stroller or wheelchair.
- Access is primarily by bus from Keikyu Zushi–Hayama Station.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/koumi-stone.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/2120/g_info/l100004030.html

place:

Area listing: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi (Yokosuka City)
text:
Title: Anjinzuka (Miura Anjin’s Memorial Mound / “Miura Anjin Grave” National Historic Site)

Datetime:
- Open year-round (outdoor site in Tsukayama Park)
- Seasonal highlight: cherry blossom season (annual Miura Anjin Festival / cherry-blossom viewing event)
- Annual memorial ceremony/festival: April 8 (held every year; the event name has changed over time)

Place:
- Tsukayama Park, Nishi-Hemmi-cho 3-chome, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area listing: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi (Yokosuka City)

Detail:
- Anjinzuka preserves two memorial pagoda-style towers (Hokyo-in-to) dedicated to Miura Anjin (William Adams) and his Japanese wife; the site is designated as the national historic site “Miura Anjin Grave.”
- William Adams (Miura Anjin), an English navigator, gained the trust of Tokugawa Ieyasu and was granted a 250-koku fief in Hemmi; he served as a diplomatic adviser and introduced Western knowledge such as gunnery, shipbuilding, and navigation.
- Tsukayama Park is also known for panoramic views; from viewpoints like “Miharashidai” and “Hill overlooking the harbor,” you can see Yokosuka Port, Sarushima, and as far as the Boso Peninsula and Yokohama.

Attention:
- No parking available.
- Access: about a 25-minute walk from Anjinzuka Station or Hemmi Station.
- Accessibility is limited (no elevators/escalators, no step-free entrance measures, and no wheelchair-accessible toilets or related universal facilities).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/anzinduka.html

title: Goshogasaki (御所ヶ崎)
datetime: N/A (outdoor landmark; visit anytime). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:22 (JST).
place: Hashirimizu area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area).
text:
Title: Goshogasaki (御所ヶ崎)

Datetime:
- N/A (outdoor landmark; visit anytime). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:22 (JST).

Place:
- Hashirimizu area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area).

Detail:
- A small cape that juts out into the sea from Hashirimizu Fishing Port.
- Local tradition says Yamato Takeru crossed to Kazusa from here; he set up a temporary palace and raised military banners, which is said to be the origin of the names “Goshogasaki” and “Hatayamazaki.”
- The cape once had Tachibana Shrine dedicated to Princess Oto-Tachibana. Legend says her comb washed ashore seven days after she threw herself into the sea, and villagers built a mausoleum on Hatayama to enshrine it.
- Later, the Edo Shogunate built a coastal battery (daiba) here. When the Meiji government purchased the area as military land, Tachibana Shrine was moved to Hashirimizu Shrine.
- Note: the site is currently not open for entry.

Attention:
- Entry is not permitted (the area is currently closed to visitors).
- No parking is available.
- Barrier-free facilities are not available (no elevator, escalator, ramps; no wheelchair-accessible restrooms or wheelchair rentals).
- Access: From Keikyu Maborikaigan Station, take a bus bound for Kannonzaki (~10 minutes) and get off at “Hashirimizu Kamimachi.”
- Contact: Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office — Tel: 046-822-8301 (09:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/gosyogasaki.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Hashirimizu, Kanagawa, Cape, Historic site, Yamato Takeru, Oto-Tachibana-hime, Coastal battery

title: Nuta Castle Remains (怒田城址)
place: Around Yoshii 1-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (walkable from Keikyu Kurihama Station / JR Kurihama Station)
text:
Title: Nuta Castle Remains (怒田城址)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:39 (timestamp shown on the source report)

Place:
- Around Yoshii 1-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (walkable from Keikyu Kurihama Station / JR Kurihama Station)

Detail:
- **What it is:** The remains of *Nuta Castle*, believed to have been built by the Miura clan, a powerful warrior family known for active maritime operations on the Miura Peninsula.
- **Historical context:** During the Kinugasa battle, Wada Yoshimori is said to have argued for fighting from the well-fortified Nuta Castle, but Miura Ōsuke Yoshiaki chose Kinugasa Castle instead. Tradition holds that, as Kinugasa Castle neared collapse, members of the Miura clan escaped via a back route to this area, then sailed toward Awa (Bōsō Peninsula). The toponym **“Funakura”** (“boat storehouse/harbor”) remains as a trace of where boats were hidden or moored.
- **Fortification & terrain:** The castle reportedly took advantage of natural landforms—described as steep and difficult to approach on three sides, with a single route opening toward the sea—making it a highly defensible position.
- **Archaeology & designation:** Today the area is protected as a Kanagawa Prefecture–designated historic site, **“Ruins centered on the Yoshii Shell Midden.”** Excavations identified multiple shell-midden locations and settlement traces spanning the Jōmon period and later eras, with the broader plateau also considered the likely location of the late-Heian mountain castle.

Attention:
- **No parking** on site.
- **Access:** About a **20-minute walk** from **Keikyu Kurihama Station** or **JR Kurihama Station**.
- **Barrier-free:** Facilities are largely unavailable (no elevator/escalator/ramps; no accessible toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing/universal sheet; no designated accessible parking; no tactile guidance blocks).
- As an archaeological/historic area, please respect signs, surrounding residences, and the landscape.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/nutazyoushi.html
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Center (09:30–17:00): +81-46-822-8301

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, castle-ruins, miura-clan, samurai-history, archaeology, jomon-period, shell-midden, historic-site, walk-from-station

Detail:
- Atagoyama Park is the oldest park in Yokosuka, opened in 1891. It was developed as a park when a memorial (spirit-inviting monument) was built for Saburosuke Nakajima, a Uraga magistrate’s officer involved in negotiations during Commodore Perry’s arrival at Uraga.
- In 1960, a monument marking the departure of the Kanrin Maru was erected to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Japan–U.S. Treaty of Amity and Commerce. The back of the monument lists crew members’ names, including Katsu Kaishu (captain), Yukichi Fukuzawa, and John Manjiro.
- The park also features a poem monument related to Tekkan and Akiko Yosano, and it offers a scenic view overlooking Uraga Port from within the grounds.

Attention:
- Parking: none.
- Access: From Keikyu “Uraga Station,” take a bus bound for Kurihama, get off at “Konyamachi,” then walk about 10 minutes.
- Accessibility (barrier-free): the report indicates no elevator, escalator, ramp/step-free entrance measures, wheelchair-accessible toilets, ostomate toilets, wheelchair rental, diaper-changing sheets, universal changing table, accessible parking, or tactile guidance blocks.
- Drones and similar devices are not permitted inside the park.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/atagoyama.html
- Official city facility page: https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/fc00000979.html

title: Japan Heritage: “Yokosuka, Kure, Sasebo, Maizuru — A Town Where You Can Feel the Pulse of Japan’s Modernization”
datetime: 2025-12-26 22:30 (captured timestamp shown on the source page)
place:
Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (featured city on the page)
Example site mentioned: Kannonsaki Battery Ruins (Second Battery), Kamoi 4-chome 1195, Yokosuka
text:
Title: Japan Heritage: “Yokosuka, Kure, Sasebo, Maizuru — A Town Where You Can Feel the Pulse of Japan’s Modernization”

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 22:30 (captured timestamp shown on the source page)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (featured city on the page)
- Example site mentioned: Kannonsaki Battery Ruins (Second Battery), Kamoi 4-chome 1195, Yokosuka

Detail:
- “Japan Heritage” is a certification by Japan’s Agency for Cultural Affairs that recognizes a *story* describing Japan’s culture and traditions through a region’s historical attractions and characteristics. The region then maintains and uses a group of tangible and intangible cultural properties to share the story strategically and revitalize the area.
- The story highlighted here explains how, in the Meiji period, Japan urgently needed coastal defense capabilities to compete with Western powers. As a national project, four natural good harbors were selected and developed into naval ports. People and cutting-edge technologies gathered in previously quiet farming and fishing villages, and infrastructure such as waterworks and railways rapidly developed alongside naval institutions—creating four naval-port cities that drove Japan’s modernization.
- Even more than a century later, many facilities remain in operation, and these former naval-port cities still attract visitors with their “somewhat nostalgic yet resilient” atmosphere.
- Yokosuka’s Japan Heritage-related constituent cultural properties include sites such as the Chiyogasaki Battery Ruins (recognized as part of the Japan Heritage narrative).
- A past tourism-related event example: On January 19, 2019, a photo session collaborating with “Sukajan” (a fashion item that originated in Yokosuka) was held at the Second Battery of the Kannonsaki Battery Ruins. The page encourages visitors to view local high school students’ photos and visit the battery ruins (about a 10-minute walk from the Yokosuka Museum of Art).
- Another past tourism initiative mentioned: a “Goshuin Cycle Rally” tied to the simultaneous special opening of two major sacred sites on the Miura Peninsula, including public release of VR images.

Attention:
- Some related facilities may still be active or have access restrictions; confirm current visiting rules and opening conditions on the official site before you go.
- For specific event information (past events, VR content, rally details), refer to the official “Past Event Details” sections on the source site.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/nihonisan/

Tags: #JapanHeritage, #Yokosuka, #Kanagawa, #MiuraPeninsula, #Modernization, #NavalPortHistory, #CoastalDefense, #CulturalHeritage

- These guardhouses stand near what used to be an entrance to the former naval port, where many military personnel once passed through.

title: East Kano Shrine (Higashi Kano Jinja)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:40 JST (timestamp shown on the source page capture)
place: East Kano Shrine, 2-21-25 Higashi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0821, Japan
text:
Title: East Kano Shrine (Higashi Kano Jinja)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 JST (timestamp shown on the source page capture)

Place:
- East Kano Shrine, 2-21-25 Higashi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0821, Japan

Detail:
- East Kano Shrine stands on the eastern side of Uraga Harbor, facing West Kano Shrine across the water.
- A well behind the shrine is linked to a local legend: Kaishū Katsu is said to have performed water purification there before the Kanrin Maru’s Pacific crossing, and then fasted on the summit of nearby Myojin-yama.
- The guardian lion-dogs (komainu) in front of the worship hall are unusual: each holds a pup, and the right one appears to be nursing; both seem to have closed mouths, creating a “pair across the harbor” story with the West shrine’s komainu.
- The shrine is popular as a “wish-granting” (kano = “to come true”) power spot. A local custom mentioned in the guide is to place a magatama charm from West Kano Shrine inside a protective pouch from East Kano Shrine to support good relationships (including romance).
- Historically, the enshrined deity is Emperor Ōjin (the same as Iwashimizu Hachimangū in Kyoto). The shrine is said to have begun on August 15, 1181, when the monk Mongaku invited the spirit of Iwashimizu Hachimangū while praying for the revival of the Genji; later, Minamoto no Yoritomo’s success led to the name “Kano Daimyōjin.”
- The wooded hill behind the shrine is Myojin-yama (about 50 meters high). It has an inner shrine (okumiya) near the summit and a marker for “Kaishū Katsu’s fasting place.”
- The Myojin-yama area is valued for its well-preserved natural forest and biodiversity; the ubamegashi (Quercus phillyraeoides) here is noted as a northern distribution limit in the prefecture. The grove is designated as a Prefectural Natural Monument (“Kano Shrine Shaso-rin”).

Attention:
- Accessibility: the site lists no elevator/escalator and no ramp/slope measures, and indicates that the route from the “Shinmachi” bus stop includes stairs.
- Parking is limited to 10 cars.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/higashi-kanou-z.html
- Official site: http://jinjya.net

Tags: yokosuka, uraga, shrine, kano-shrine, history-and-culture, power-spot, myojinyama, komainu, ferry-crossing

title: Yokosuka Cycling: Routes, Share Bikes, and Rider Support
place: Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Yokosuka Cycling: Routes, Share Bikes, and Rider Support

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 21:46 (JST) *(source page snapshot time)*

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Yokosuka City is a popular cycling destination that can be reached from central Tokyo in about one hour. Riders can enjoy a mix of nature and urban scenery, with varied roads that make for a dynamic ride.
- Food is also part of the experience: Yokosuka highlights fresh seafood and local mountain produce, making it easy to plan a ride around meals.
- The official **Yokosuka City Cycling Map** introduces three main courses:
- **“Gurutto Skychi!” (68 km)** — a longer loop to cover many highlights.
- **East Coast Route (26 km)**
- **West Coast Route (23 km)**
- If you run into trouble while riding, Yokosuka partners with the local taxi association to offer a paid support service called **“CYCLE RESCUE TAXI YOKOSUKA”**, which can transport both rider and bicycle safely to a destination such as your home or a station.
- For short-distance sightseeing, Yokosuka also offers **electric-assist share cycles**. You can pick up and return bikes at different stations (one-way drop-off), and the service is usable via smartphone through **HELLO CYCLING** (external site). A call center is available for support.

Attention:
- **Cycle Rescue Taxi is a paid service.** Keep the taxi company phone numbers handy in case of emergencies.
- Share-cycle support: **HELLO CYCLING Call Center: 050-3821-8282**.
- Follow Japan’s bicycle safety principles:
- Roads are the default (sidewalks are exceptions).
- Keep left on the roadway.
- On sidewalks, prioritize pedestrians and ride slowly near the roadway side.
- Obey rules: no drunk riding, no doubling, no riding side-by-side; use lights at night; stop and check safety at intersections.
- Children should wear helmets.
- Avoid riding in large groups, and share the road thoughtfully with pedestrians, cyclists, and cars.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/special/cycling.html

Tags: yokosuka, cycling, bike-routes, east-coast, west-coast, share-cycle, electric-assist, rescue-taxi, kanagawa, japan

Detail:
- A day-use hot spring facility in Yokosuka featuring natural onsen water drawn from about 1,800 meters underground. The spring is salty and known for strong heat-retention, and the open-air bath offers views over Tokyo Bay while ships pass by.
- On-site amenities include a stone sauna (ganbanyoku) using four types of minerals, a restaurant (“Tenpu”), body care services, scrub/beauty treatments, and an ocean-view relaxation area—making it suitable for spending a full day.

Attention:
- Hours: 09:00–24:00 (last entry 23:00).
- Admission (incl. rental bath + face towels):

- Children (age 4–elementary): Weekdays ¥600 / Weekends & holidays ¥700.
- Age 3 and under: Free (no towel rental for ages 0–3).
- Stone sauna (ganbanyoku): Adults only (not available for elementary school age or younger). Weekdays ¥550 / Weekends & specified days ¥600 / Weekday night after 21:00 ¥450 (includes rental wear + large towel).
- Open year-round, but there may be maintenance closures about twice per year.
- Accessibility (highlights): elevator available; wheelchair-accessible toilets and ostomate toilet available; no wheelchair loan service. Wheelchair use is limited up to the changing room area.

- Opened in 2007 to commemorate Yokosuka City’s 100th anniversary.
- Located in scenic Kannonzaki, overlooking Tokyo Bay; known as a “scenic-view museum” with outstanding outdoor views surrounded by greenery.

- Collection highlights include works by artists connected to Yokosuka and the Miura Peninsula, plus selected masterpieces from about 6,000 modern and contemporary Japanese artworks.
- Features a permanent display of works by Rokuro Taniuchi (famous for “Shukan Shincho” cover illustrations), known for a nostalgic, relaxing atmosphere.
- On-site facilities include the Italian restaurant “Aqua Mare” (headed by a renowned chef) and a museum shop.

Detail:
- A full-scale opera-house style venue equipped with some of the highest-level stage facilities in Japan.
- It hosts international competitions and large-scale productions, offering high-quality performing arts.
- The site has a unique cultural history: before WWII it was a gathering hall for the Imperial Japanese Navy’s NCOs and enlisted personnel; after the war it became a U.S. Navy enlisted men’s club (EM Club), where many Japanese jazz musicians developed and American culture spread nationwide.
- Yokosuka-specific performances are held annually, such as “Yokosuka Jazz Dreams” and events featuring the U.S. Navy 7th Fleet Band.

Attention:

- JR Yokosuka Station: ~8 minutes on foot

- Mt. Takeyama, Take 1-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area).
- Elevation: about 200 m.
- Viewpoint: panoramic views of Tokyo Bay and Sagami Bay; on clear days you may see Mt. Fuji.

Detail:
- Mt. Takeyama is a popular nature spot known for its azaleas (about 1,200 shrubs planted near the summit).
- A hiking route is maintained connecting Mt. Takeyama to nearby peaks such as Hodaiyama (Battery Hill) and Miura Fuji.
- Near the summit you can visit Takeyama Fudo-in (Ryuzukasan Jikyoji Takeyama Fudo-in), the first site of the Miura Peninsula pilgrimage.
- During azalea season, the summit area becomes especially scenic; some azaleas grow tall enough to form a “red tunnel,” making it a good place for a picnic.

Attention:
- No parking available.
- Access includes a bus + a long walk:
- From Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station or JR Yokosuka Station: take a bus bound for the Nagai area (e.g., “Nagai,” “Misakiguchi,” etc.), get off at “Ikizuka,” then walk about 40 minutes.
- From Keikyu YRP Nobi Station: take the “Shimin Byoin” (City Hospital) bus, get off at “Ikizuka,” then walk about 40 minutes.
- Barrier-free notes (as listed):
- No elevator / escalator / slope measures at entrances.
- No wheelchair-accessible toilets, ostomate toilets, wheelchair rental, diaper-changing facilities, or accessible parking.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/takeyama.html

Tags: yokosuka, miura_peninsula, hiking, viewpoint, azalea, festival, temple, nature

title: Takeyama Fudoin Temple (Takeyama Fudo)
datetime: Annual events: January 28 (Hatsufudo / first Fudo day, principal image 공개 viewing); late April to May (Takeyama Azalea Festival / Tsutsuji Matsuri)
place:
Takeyama area, Yokosuka City (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama)
Address: 1-3040 Take, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Takeyama Fudoin Temple (Takeyama Fudo)

Datetime:
- Annual events: January 28 (Hatsufudo / first Fudo day, principal image 공개 viewing); late April to May (Takeyama Azalea Festival / Tsutsuji Matsuri)

Place:
- Takeyama area, Yokosuka City (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama)
- Address: 1-3040 Take, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A mountaintop temple dedicated to Fudo Myoo (Acala), revered locally as “Namikiri Fudo” for maritime safety. It has long been worshiped by fishermen and seafarers as a protector for safe voyages and good catches.
- The approach routes spread in multiple directions, and “Mae-Fudo” statues (Fudo Myoo images) stand near trailheads as guides for visitors.
- Around the summit, roughly 2,000 azaleas bloom, and the Takeyama Azalea Festival is held each spring.
- A hiking network connects Mt. Takeyama with nearby peaks such as Hotaiyama and Miura Fuji.
- From the rooftop observatory amid the azaleas, you can enjoy wide views over Tokyo Bay and the Boso Peninsula; on clear days you may see Izu Oshima, the Izu Peninsula across Sagami Bay, and Mt. Fuji. The viewpoint is recognized in the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism’s “Kanto Fujimi 100 Views.”

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- From the bus stop, expect about a 40-minute walk to reach the temple.
- Barrier-free facilities are generally not available (elevators/escalators/accessible toilets, etc.). Contact the temple in advance if you need assistance.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/takeyama-fudo.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Temple, Fudo Myoo, Hiking, Azalea, Mt. Fuji view, January festival, Spring flowers

title: Uraga no Watashi (Ferryboat) — “Ponpon Boat” in Uraga, Yokosuka
place:
Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Ferry terminals:
East Pier: Higashi-Uraga 2-19-10 (nearby)
West Pier: Nishi-Uraga 1-2-19 (nearby)
text:
Title: Uraga no Watashi (Ferryboat) — “Ponpon Boat” in Uraga, Yokosuka

Datetime:
- Accessed: 2025-12-26 19:34 (JST)

Place:
- Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Ferry terminals:
- East Pier: Higashi-Uraga 2-19-10 (nearby)
- West Pier: Nishi-Uraga 1-2-19 (nearby)

Detail:
- A small local ferry affectionately nicknamed the “Ponpon Boat,” and a symbol of Uraga. It is a practical way for residents and visitors to move between the east and west sides of Uraga, separated by the harbor.
- There is no fixed timetable: when the boat is on the opposite bank, you press the call button and it comes over.
- The crossing takes about 3 minutes, and you can enjoy views from the water—including cranes and docks on the former Uraga shipyard site.
- The current vessel is “Atagomaru,” an FRP (reinforced plastic) boat inspired by Edo-period “gozabune” style. Capacity is 12 passengers plus 1 crew, in service since 1998-08-09.
- The ferry has a long history, believed to date back to around 1725. The route is also known as “Uraga Kaido,” a rare “waterborne city road” (Route No. 2073).

Attention:
- Hours: 07:00–17:00
- Service may be suspended due to rough seas/strong winds or during vessel inspections (sometimes operated flexibly—check before you go).
- Parking: None
- Accessibility (barrier-free): Not equipped with elevators/escalators/ramps; wheelchair-accessible toilets and wheelchair rental are not available.
- Fares (one-way):
- Adult: 400 JPY
- Elementary & Junior High: 200 JPY
- Preschool child: Free (1 per adult; additional children charged at the student fare)
- Under 1 year: Free
- Bicycle, etc.: 50 JPY
- Strollers & pets: Free
- Large luggage that uses a seat: 50 JPY
- Disability discount available; Yokosuka residents pay half price.

Link:
- Tourism info page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/uraga-watashi.html
- Official site: https://ponponsen.jp
- Contact (operator): +81-46-825-7144 (Triangle Co., Ltd.)

title: Uraga Dock (Uraga Brick Dry Dock) — Limited-Visit Industrial Heritage Spot
place:
Uraga 4-7, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga
Access: About a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Uraga Station
text:
Title: Uraga Dock (Uraga Brick Dry Dock) — Limited-Visit Industrial Heritage Spot

Datetime:
- Report snapshot: 2025-12-26 19:31 (JST)

Place:
- Uraga 4-7, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga
- Access: About a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Uraga Station

Detail:
- When you go down the stairs at Uraga Station, you can see large shipyard-era buildings and cranes (some parts have been dismantled). This site is the former Sumitomo Heavy Industries Uraga shipyard, where shipbuilding continued for more than a century and produced about 1,000 vessels.
- Until the site closed in 2003, ships such as Nippon Maru, Kaiwo Maru, Seikan ferry boats, and escort ships were built here, and the town was lively with shipyard workers.
- The brick dry dock (built in 1899) is the only place in Japan where you can see this type of brick dry dock.
- In 2021, the area including the dock was donated from Sumitomo Heavy Industries to Yokosuka City.
- Background (history overview): Shipbuilding in Uraga dates back to 1854, and the company that later became known as “Uraga Dock” was established in 1897; the dry dock was completed two years later, and the yard went through multiple name changes before closing in 2003.

Attention:
- Uraga Dock can be visited **only on designated public-opening days** (events or limited tours).
- Accessibility is limited: elevators, escalators, step-free entrance measures, accessible toilets, wheelchair rental, baby changing facilities, and accessible parking are listed as not available.
- Viewing routes and what you can enter may vary by the tour/event; in some cases, structures can be viewed from outside the site.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/uragadock.html
- https://www.wakuwaku-yokosuka.jp/uragarengadock.php

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Uraga Dock, Industrial heritage, Brick dry dock, Shipbuilding history, Limited opening, Kanagawa

text:
Title: Nagahama Beach (Wada Nagahama Beach) — Yokosuka “Beach Special”

Datetime:
- Swimming season (beach opening period): 2025-07-05 (Sat) – 2025-08-31 (Sun)
- Beach house (umi-no-ie) open: 2025-07-05 (Sat) – 2025-08-31 (Sun)
- Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office phone hours: 09:30–17:00

Place:
- Wada Nagahama Beach (often nicknamed “Nahama”), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- A locally loved beach with a wide sandy shore and a relaxed atmosphere—especially suitable for families with children.
- Rocky areas on both sides make it a good spot for snorkeling.
- Nearby attractions include Soleil Hill and Arasaki Park.
- Facilities:
- 1 paid rest area with changing rooms and showers
- Rentals available (e.g., swim rings)
- Beach house contact:
- Wada Nagahama Gourmet Park (Contact: Saito) +81-90-4705-4389
- Access:
- By bus: From Keikyu Misakiguchi Station, take a bus (e.g., Arasaki / Shimin Byoin / Yokosuka Station routes) for ~5 minutes to “Wada,” then walk ~15 minutes.
- By car: From Kinugasa IC (Yokohama–Yokosuka Road), via the Miura Jukan Road to Route 134 toward Misaki (~4 km). Parking available.

Attention:
- The Kannonnzaki coast is *not* a designated swimming beach.
- Beaches are generally non-smoking; if you smoke, use designated smoking areas.
- Reports indicate blue-ringed octopus sightings in Kanagawa. Its saliva contains potent toxins (e.g., tetrodotoxin); do not touch small octopuses during tidepooling or swimming.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/special/beach.html
- Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office: +81-46-822-8301

title: Umibe Fishing Park (海辺つり公園)
place: 3-1 Heiseicho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa 238-0013, Japan (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area)
text:
Title: Umibe Fishing Park (海辺つり公園)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:29 JST (page capture time)

Place:
- 3-1 Heiseicho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa 238-0013, Japan (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area)

Detail:
- Umibe Fishing Park is a popular waterfront fishing spot where you can enjoy sea fishing while looking out toward Sarushima Island and the Boso Peninsula.
- The main highlight is a fishing boardwalk that stretches about 500 meters, allowing year-round sea fishing.
- There is also a lawn area, making it family-friendly for a relaxed outing.
- Admission is free, and individual use is generally open. If a group plans to use the park, advance consultation is requested.
- Access: about a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Horinouchi Station.
- Hours: 05:00–22:00. No regular closing days, but the park may close due to weather conditions.
- Parking: 95 standard-size car spaces, open 24 hours.
- 07:00–22:00: 320 JPY for the first hour, +160 JPY per additional 30 minutes (cap: 640 JPY per visit during this time window)
- 22:00–07:00: 100 JPY per hour
- Walk connection: This area is part of the “10,000m Promenade,” a roughly 10 km seaside walking route continuing from JR Yokosuka Station through Heiseicho toward Hashirimizu’s boardwalk and Kannonzaki, with great Tokyo Bay views (Sarushima, the Dai-1/Dai-2 Kaiho sea forts, Yokohama’s landmarks and Bay Bridge, the Aqua-Line, and the Boso Peninsula).
- Fishing advice: Staff from the local fishing tackle maker “YAMASHITA & Maria” can support beginners as “Fishing Advisors” (YAMARIA Corporation, TEL 045-716-5705).
- Accessibility (selected items):
- Entrance step reduction (incl. ramps): available
- Wheelchair-accessible restroom: available
- Diaper changing sheet: available
- Disabled parking: available (2 spaces)
- Elevator / escalator / wheelchair rental: not available

Attention:
- If you plan to visit as a group, contact the park in advance.
- The park can close due to bad weather—check conditions before you go.
- Drones (and similar devices) are not permitted inside the park.
- Accessibility is partial (no elevator/escalator and no wheelchair rental), so plan accordingly if needed.

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourism Info page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/turi-park.html
- Official site (Kanagawa Parks): https://www.kanagawaparks.com/umibeturi/

Tags: Yokosuka, Tokyo Bay, Fishing, Boardwalk, Free admission, Family-friendly, Seaside walk, Sarushima view, Accessible restroom

title: Awashima Shrine (Awashima Jinja)
datetime: Annual ritual festival: March 3 (Hinamatsuri / Peach Festival). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 19:03 (JST).
place: 1-18-29 Ashina, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area).
text:
Title: Awashima Shrine (Awashima Jinja)

Datetime:
- Annual ritual festival: March 3 (Hinamatsuri / Peach Festival). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 19:03 (JST).

Place:
- 1-18-29 Ashina, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area).

Detail:
- Awashima Shrine is said to have been enshrined here from Awashima Shrine in Kada (present-day Kada, Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture). It has long been worshiped across the Miura Peninsula since at least the Edo period, especially as a shrine for matchmaking and safe voyages.
- A well-known local rite is to dedicate a *bottomless ladle* (a ladle with the bottom removed) tied with hemp. This custom expresses prayers for safe childbirth—“as water drains out, may the birth go smoothly”—and is held on March 3.
- During the festival, Shinto priests and shrine maidens board a boat from Ashina Beach in front of the shrine and perform a “floating hina dolls” ritual (nagashi-bina).
- The west coast area of Yokosuka has several related spots connected with safe childbirth and matchmaking, such as Junisho Shrine and Akiya’s “Kosan-ishi” (Childbirth Stone).
- Access (public transit): From Keikyu Shin-Zushi Station, take a bus toward Nagai (e.g., bound for Yokosuka City Hospital or Nagai; about 25 minutes). Get off at “Ashina” bus stop, then walk about 15 minutes.

Attention:
- No parking available on site.
- Barrier-free facilities are limited (e.g., no elevators/escalators, no wheelchair-accessible toilets). Wheelchair users can worship in front of the main hall, but entry into the hall is not permitted.
- Contact: Yokosuka Tourist Information Office (Tel: +81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/awashima-z.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, shrine, history-and-culture, matchmaking, safe-childbirth, maritime-safety, hinamatsuri, floating-hina-dolls

title: Kumano Shrine (Kumano Jinja)
place: 6-16-25 Nagai, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Nagai / Arasaki area)
text:
Title: Kumano Shrine (Kumano Jinja)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:11 (JST)

Place:
- 6-16-25 Nagai, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Nagai / Arasaki area)

Detail:
- Kumano Shrine is the principal guardian shrine of the entire Nagai area and is affectionately called “Gongensama” by locals.
- Tradition says it was founded in the Kenkyu era (1190–1199), when Ienaga (the eldest son of Suzuki Shigeie, a retainer of Minamoto no Yoshitsune) enshrined Kumano Gongen from Kishu (his hometown) at this site.
- A monument beside the stone stairway records the names of fish and dried-fish wholesalers from Nihonbashi (Edo) who donated to create the steps, hinting at the Kumano faith among fishing communities and historical ties between Nagai and Edo.

Attention:
- The approach includes stone steps and the site has limited barrier-free support (no elevators, escalators, ramps, accessible toilets, wheelchair rental, accessible parking, guidance blocks, or diaper-changing facilities). Plan accordingly if you need step-free access.
- Access by bus: from Keikyu Misakiguchi Station, take the “Arasaki” bus (~30 min), get off at “Urushiyama,” then walk about 5 minutes.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kumano-z.html
- Phone: +81-46-857-7177

Tags: Yokosuka, Nagai, Arasaki, Shrine, History, Cultural heritage, Kumano faith, Accessibility

title: Tomyodo Lighthouse (燈明堂)
place: Nishi-Uraga 6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Tomyodo Lighthouse (燈明堂)

Datetime:
- Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:39 (JST)

Place:
- Nishi-Uraga 6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Tomyodo Lighthouse stands on the west side of Uraga Port and historically served as a navigation light for ships entering and leaving the harbor. It was built in 1648 by order of the shogunate, and its rapeseed-oil lamp was said to be visible up to about 4 nautical miles (7.4 km) offshore.
- From the Genroku era onward, it was maintained at the expense of East Uraga's dried-sardine (hoshi-iwashi) wholesalers. It reportedly operated every day for about 220 years, protecting the shipping route until it was abolished in 1872.
- The original structure remained into the 1880s but later collapsed due to weather, leaving only the stone base. In 1988, the current building was reconstructed on the remaining stonework to match the historical exterior.
- A small sandy beach stretches from Tomyodo, and you can still see many vessels passing offshore today.
- Admission: Free.
- Access: From Keikyu Uraga Station, take a bus bound for Keikyu Kurihama Station via Chiyogasaki (about 8 minutes). Get off at “Tomyodo Iriguchi” bus stop, then walk about 5 minutes.
- Parking: Nearby “Tomyodo Green Space” parking is available.
- Contact: Yokosuka Tourist Information Center (Tel: +81-46-822-8301, 9:30–17:00).

Attention:
- Accessibility (barrier-free): Not well equipped. No elevator or escalator, and no slope/step-free entrance measures are listed. No accessible toilet, no ostomate toilet, no wheelchair rental, no diaper-changing sheet, and no universal (adult) changing sheet. There is one dedicated parking space for people with disabilities, but no guidance blocks are listed.
- If you need step-free access or accessible restrooms, plan accordingly and consider checking the latest conditions before visiting.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/toumyoudou.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Tomyodo, lighthouse, historic site, coastal walk, free admission, Kanagawa
