title: Sarushima Park (Sarushima)
place:
Sarushima 1, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0019, Japan
Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi (Yokosuka City)
text:
Title: Sarushima Park (Sarushima)

Datetime:
- Accessed: 2025-12-26 20:29 (JST)

Place:
- Sarushima 1, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0019, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi (Yokosuka City)

Detail:
- Sarushima is the only natural island in Tokyo Bay, reachable by a short ferry ride (about 10 minutes) from Mikasa Pier. fileciteturn1file1L2-L4
- The island is known for outdoor activities year-round, including fishing, barbecues, and (in season) swimming. fileciteturn1file1L2-L9
- It also offers a “mini-adventure” atmosphere: you can explore former military fortress remains such as brick tunnels, gun-battery ruins, and cut-through paths. fileciteturn1file1L4-L8 fileciteturn1file3L12-L20
- A highlight is the historic brickwork—some tunnels use the rare “French bond” brick pattern. fileciteturn1file3L15-L17
- Spring and autumn may feature fishing tournaments (check the operator’s site for details). fileciteturn1file1L8-L10

Attention:
- Getting there:
- Walk to Mikasa Pier from Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station (about 15 minutes) or from JR Yokosuka Station (about 30 minutes), then take the ferry (about 10 minutes). fileciteturn1file0L12-L17
- Fees (typical):
- Ferry round-trip: Adults 1,500 JPY; Elementary school students 750 JPY (group discounts available). fileciteturn1file0L17-L20
- Park admission: 500 JPY for ages 15+ (excluding middle school students); 250 JPY for elementary & middle school students. fileciteturn1file0L21-L23
- Ferry operating hours:
- Mar 1 – late Oct: 09:30–17:00
- Nov 1 – late Feb: 09:30–16:00
- Note: the last ferry is earlier in winter; extra boats may run depending on crowd levels; ferries may be cancelled in bad weather. fileciteturn1file0L24-L33
- Park rules / restrictions (examples):
- Drones are not permitted in the park. fileciteturn1file3L3-L5
- Organizing group photo/video “shooting events” and occupying areas for large-scale subject photography are prohibited. fileciteturn1file4L1-L5

text:
Title: Taura Plum Grove (Taura Ume-no-Sato)

Datetime:
- Early Feb–Early Mar: Taura Plum Grove Festival (typical annual schedule)
- Late Feb–Mid Mar: peak plum blossoms (best fragrance and views)
- Dec–Mar: daffodils bloom
- Early May: azaleas near the observation deck

Place:
- 92 Taura Izumi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Oppama/Taura area)

Detail:
- A famous plum-blossom spot with over 2,000 plum trees, selected as one of the “Kanagawa Flower Spots 100.”
- About 6,000 m² in size and known as the only plum grove on the Miura Peninsula.
- Family-friendly facilities include an athletic playground that uses the natural terrain, a lawn plaza, and an observation deck with great views.
- History: started in 1934 when local residents planted about 700 plum trees; later city plantings expanded the grove to today’s scale, including varieties such as Aojiku, Shirokaga (white plum), and Yoro (red plum).

Attention:
- Free admission. No fixed opening hours. No parking available.
- Access:
- From Keihin-Taura Station: take a bus bound for “Yasura 2-chome” (~10 min), get off at “Taura Post Office,” then walk ~15 min.
- From JR Taura Station: ~20 min on foot.
- Accessibility (barrier-free): many features are not available (elevators, escalators, ramps, accessible toilets, wheelchair rental, etc.), but wheelchairs can reach the park entrance.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/umenosato.html
- Flowering information (official): http://taura.y-parks.jp/flowering.html

title: Mt. Houdaiyama (Gun Battery Ruins) — Hiking Spot in Yokosuka
datetime:
Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:41 (JST)
Note: This is a place/spot guide (not an event listing).
place:
Houdaiyama (Otsukayama on the Miura Fuji → Takeyama hiking route)
Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Mt. Houdaiyama (Gun Battery Ruins) — Hiking Spot in Yokosuka

Datetime:
- Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:41 (JST)
- Note: This is a place/spot guide (not an event listing).

Place:
- Houdaiyama (Otsukayama on the Miura Fuji → Takeyama hiking route)
- Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- Houdaiyama is the nickname for Otsukayama along the hiking course that runs from Miura Fuji to Mt. Takeyama. It became known as “Houdaiyama” because the Imperial Japanese Navy built a gun battery here in the early Shōwa period.
- At the summit, there is the Japan Coast Guard’s Takeyama Receiving Station, enclosed by fencing, with prominent parabolic antennas.
- Next to the facility, a well-preserved, mortar-bowl-shaped gun emplacement (battery remains) can still be seen. A high-angle gun was once installed at the center.
- Eight square openings on the side are thought to have been ammunition storage spaces.

Attention:
- Access is a long walk (about 80 minutes on foot from Keikyū Nagasawa Station).
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility/barrier-free features are not provided (no elevator/escalator/ramps; wheelchair-accessible facilities are not available).
- Water facilities are at the Mt. Takeyama summit restroom (not at Houdaiyama itself), so plan water and restroom breaks accordingly.

Link:
- Official spot page (Yokosuka City tourism): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/houdaiyama.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Miura Peninsula, Akiya, Sajima, Takeyama, Hiking, Nature, Historic Site, Shōwa era, Gun battery ruins, Coastal defense history, Parabolic antenna

text:
Title: Akiya and Tateishi Beach (Akiya・Tateishi Coast)

Datetime:
- Open year-round (recommended time: sunset, especially when Mt. Fuji is visible behind Tateishi Rock)

Place:
- 3-5 Akiya, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama
- Coordinates (approx.): 35°14'27.3"N 139°35'51.9"E

Detail:
- A scenic coastline famous for the huge rock formation called “Tateishi,” which juts out into the sea.
- The view of Tateishi Rock with Mt. Fuji in the background is a classic viewpoint—sunset is especially impressive.
- Unlike the Tokyo Bay side, this area retains more natural coastline.
- The landscape around Akiya was depicted in the Edo period by ukiyo-e artist Andō Hiroshige (Utagawa Hiroshige).

Attention:
- Parking: Kanagawa Prefectural Tateishi Parking Lot (free). Large vehicles cannot park due to a narrow entrance.
- Parking hours: 6:00–20:00 (Jul 1–Aug 31); 24 hours (outside that period).
- Barrier-free notes (at/around the site): no elevator/escalator; wheelchair-accessible toilet available; ostomate toilet available; diaper-changing sheet available; wheelchair rental not available; accessible parking spaces available (2).
- Inquiries: Yokosuka Tourist Information Office (Tel. +81-46-822-8301, 9:30–17:00). Parking office Tel. +81-46-853-8800 (Kanagawa Prefecture Yokosuka Civil Engineering Office).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/akiya-beach.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/fc00000486.html

Title: No. 2 Sea Fort Landing Tour (Daini Kaihō)

- Meeting/Departure (access info): Mikasa Pier area, Yokosuka, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- “No. 2 Sea Fort” is an artificial island built from the Meiji to Taishō eras to defend the capital (Tokyo). It was created to install coastal artillery and is described as a domestically built island using the latest technology of its time.
- Landing on the island was permitted in the final year of the Heisei era, and visitors can experience historical remnants on-site.
- Access to Mikasa Pier:
- About 15 minutes on foot from Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station
- About 30 minutes on foot from JR Yokosuka Station
- By car: about 3 km from Yokosuka IC (Yokohama-Yokosuka Road) via Honcho-Yamanaka Road to Mikasa Pier
- Parking: use nearby paid parking lots.

Attention:
- Barrier-free facilities are not available (e.g., no elevators/escalators; no wheelchair-accessible toilets; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing facilities).
- Tour recruitment/availability is handled per tour—check the official website for the latest information.
- Inquiries: +81-46-825-5401 (10:00–16:00, excluding weekends and public holidays).

title: Wakayama Bokusui Monument (Couple Poem Monument)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:45 JST (timestamp shown on the source page capture)
place: Nagasawa Beach, Nagasawa 2-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa (Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama area)
text:
Title: Wakayama Bokusui Monument (Couple Poem Monument)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:45 JST (timestamp shown on the source page capture)

Place:
- Nagasawa Beach, Nagasawa 2-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa (Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama area)

Detail:
- The seaside in front of the Nagaoka Hantaro Memorial Museum & Wakayama Bokusui Museum has been developed as a small park, where two stone poem monuments by the tanka poet Wakayama Bokusui stand.
- The monument on the right (facing the sea) is known as the “couple poem monument.” It features Bokusui’s famous poem about a swan on the front, and a poem by his wife, Kishiko, carved on the back.
- Bokusui moved to the Kita-Shitaura area in March 1915 for his wife’s recuperation. During their stay (less than two years), he is said to have published poetry collections, enjoyed local food and sake, and spent time fishing in the nearby river.
- The museum nearby exhibits many materials and photographs that recall this period, and a “Kita-Shitaura Bokusui Festival” is held every September.
- Practical info: about a 12-minute walk from Keikyu Nagasawa Station; no parking.

Attention:
- There is no dedicated parking, so public transport is recommended.
- Accessibility features are limited (no elevators/escalators; no wheelchair-accessible toilet or rental wheelchair reported), so visitors who need step-free access should plan ahead.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/bokusuikahi.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/2120/g_info/l100004004.html

title: Arasaki Park (Arasaki Koen)
datetime: 2025-12-26 18:59 JST (retrieved from the Yokosuka tourism site snapshot in the report)
place: Arasaki Park, Nagai 6-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Nagai / Arasaki area)
text:
Title: Arasaki Park (Arasaki Koen)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 18:59 JST (retrieved from the Yokosuka tourism site snapshot in the report)

Place:
- Arasaki Park, Nagai 6-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Nagai / Arasaki area)

Detail:
- **What it is:** A coastal park along the Arasaki shoreline, known for dramatic rock formations created by natural erosion and layered geology.
- **Highlights:**
- **Sunset Hill (“Yūhi no Oka”)**: A viewpoint deck overlooking Sagami Bay, with distant views that can include **Mt. Fuji** and the **Amagi Mountains**. The silhouette of Mt. Fuji against the sunset is described as a standout scene.
- **Coastal walk:** The area features a rugged, steep ria-style coastline and scenic strolling routes.
- **Notable spots nearby/around the coast:** Jūmonji Cave, Benten Island, and “bat cave” style rock hollows are mentioned as points of interest.
- **Picnic Hill:** A circular lawn plaza surrounded by forest—good for spreading out lunch while still being near the sea.
- **Seasonal flowers:** Daffodils start blooming around mid-January near Sunset Hill, adding a fragrant, atmospheric feel.
- **Access:**
- **By bus:** From Keikyu Misakiguchi Station, take a bus bound for Arasaki (about 30 minutes), get off at “Arasaki” bus stop, then walk about 5 minutes.
- **By car:** Via Yokohama–Yokosuka Road → Miura-Jukan Expressway to the end, then follow Route 134 south and turn at the “Arasaki Iriguchi” intersection; about 10 minutes from there.

Attention:
- **Rocks and shoreline can be slippery.** Use sturdy shoes and be mindful of tides and waves (especially when walking close to the water).
- **Drone use is not permitted** inside the park.
- **Parking rules vary by season/time:** 89 spaces (including a few large-vehicle spaces). Weekends/holidays and **Jul 20–Aug 31** are typically paid periods; motorcycles have free parking spaces.
- **Limited barrier-free facilities:** No elevators/escalators, no wheelchair-accessible toilets or wheelchair rental; there are **2 accessible parking spaces** for people with disabilities, and an indicated barrier-free route from the Arasaki bus stop.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/arasaki-park.html
- https://arasaki.soleil-park.jp/

Tags: Yokosuka, Nagai, Arasaki, coastal park, scenic viewpoint, sunset, Mt. Fuji view, rocky shore, walking trail, daffodils, parking, accessibility

title: Ruins of Kinugasa Castle (Kinugasa-jōshi)
place: Kinugasa area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (near the Kinugasa IC entrance on the Yokohama–Yokosuka Road)
text:
Title: Ruins of Kinugasa Castle (Kinugasa-jōshi)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:57 JST

Place:
- Kinugasa area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (near the Kinugasa IC entrance on the Yokohama–Yokosuka Road)

Detail:
- A historic hilltop/medieval mountain-castle site that once served as the main stronghold of the **Miura clan**, a powerful local family on the Miura Peninsula from the late Heian to early Kamakura periods.
- The fortress was a **natural-terrain castle** (no stone walls or moats like later castles). Rivers such as the **Miyama River** and **Ōyato River** are thought to have functioned as natural defensive lines.
- The site is closely tied to the **Battle of Kinugasa (1180)**, when a much larger Taira (Heike) force attacked the Miura defenders—an episode connected to the opening era of the Kamakura period.
- Today it is mainly enjoyed as a **short historical hike / walk**, with points of interest including:
- **“Uma-kaeshi no Saka” (Horse-turning Slope):** a notably steep ascent on the route toward the main area.
- **Fudō Waterfall (Fudō no Taki):** a spring/water spot below Daizen-ji, linked to a local legend and considered important for daily and defensive water use.
- **Momiiwa (Lookout Rock):** a large boulder said to have been used to observe and direct the battle; artifacts were reportedly found nearby during early 20th‑century site works.
- **Yatake bamboo (arrow bamboo):** bamboo historically used as arrow material; the surrounding “Yabe” place-name is associated with arrow-making traditions.
- **Seki Jizō (Cough Jizō):** a small Jizō statue tied to a story from the battle; locally associated with relief from coughs.
- **Karamete-guchi (rear gate route):** a narrow cut-through path said to have been heavily defended; nearby are traces of earthworks, training-ground areas, and old wells.

Attention:
- **No parking available.**
- The route inside the historic area is **unpaved** and includes **steep slopes and stairs**—wear shoes with good grip and allow extra time.
- Barrier-free facilities are essentially **not available** (e.g., no elevators/escalators; no wheelchair-accessible toilets or rentals). Plan accordingly.
- For official guidance, contact the **Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office**: +81-46-822-8301 (9:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kinugasa-zyoushi.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kinugasa, Castle ruins, Miura clan, Kamakura period, Heian period, History & culture, Hiking / walking trail, Battle site, Scenic lookout

- Kinugasayama Park is one of Kanagawa’s best-known cherry blossom viewing spots, with roughly **2,000 cherry trees** (some local descriptions also mention about **3,000 trees** in the wider park area).
- The park connects to a hiking route toward **Mt. Okusu (242 m)**, letting visitors enjoy Miura Peninsula nature.
- Next to the park is **Kinugasa Castle Ruins**, a mountain-castle site built in the early 11th century and associated with the Miura clan.

title: West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja) — Uraga, Yokosuka (Kanagawa, Japan)
place:
West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja)
Address: 1-1-13 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan
text:
Title: West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja) — Uraga, Yokosuka (Kanagawa, Japan)

Datetime:
- 12/26/25, 8:39 PM (page capture timestamp)

Place:
- West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja)
- Address: 1-1-13 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan

Detail:
- **Overview / origin:** The shrine is associated with the title “Kano Myojin” (“the deity that grants wishes”). Tradition says the monk Mongaku prayed for the revival of the Minamoto clan by enshrining (inviting) the spirit of Iwashimizu Hachimangu; after the wish was fulfilled, the shrine received the title “Kano Myojin.” It is said to have begun in 1181, and the enshrined deity is Emperor Ojin (as with Iwashimizu Hachimangu).
- **Architecture & craftsmanship:** The current shrine building was rebuilt in 1842 (after a loss in 1837). A major highlight is the extremely elaborate interior decoration, including more than 230 carvings around the shrine precincts, attributed to the Awa sculptor Goto Rihei. Look for the coffered ceiling carvings of flowers and birds (including motifs believed not to have existed in Japan at the time), and try to find the hidden wrestler figure said to be supporting a ridgepost.
- **Komainu (guardian dogs):** The komainu in front of the shrine appear to have open mouths on both sides. There is also a “hidden” cute komainu—partly concealed near a pillar—so keep an eye out.
- **Plaster relief art (Kote-e):** At the entrance of the shrine office, there is a white relief decoration made with trowel-and-plaster technique (“kote-e”). It is said to be a work from 1930 (Showa 5) by Ishikawa Zenkichi, a nationally known master of plaster craft (“Miura no Zenkichi”).
- **Power-spot style visit:** The shrine is popular as a “wish-granting” spot. A local practice says that if you place West Kano Shrine’s magatama (comma-shaped jewel) into the amulet pouch from East Kano Shrine and carry it with you, it may help bring good relationships (including romance). The East and West Kano Shrines are connected by the “Uraga no Watashi” ferry that crosses Uraga harbor.
- **Festival culture:** A tiger dance (Tora Odori), designated as an intangible folk cultural property, is offered at the annual festival in September and is said to have been passed down locally since 1720.
- **Nearby historical notes:** A monument commemorates Emperor Meiji resting here on May 18, 1881, when he came to observe the construction progress of the Kannonzaki battery.

Attention:
- **Hours:** 8:30–17:00 (worship/prayer is possible all day). No regular closing days.
- **Access by transit:** From Keikyu Uraga Station, take a bus toward Kurihama Station (~5 min), get off at “Konyamachi,” then walk ~1 minute.
- **Accessibility:** The site information indicates no elevator/escalator and no ramp/step-free entrance measures. There is no wheelchair-accessible toilet or wheelchair rental listed. The route from Konyamachi bus stop includes stairs.
- **Suggested itinerary:** If you want to try the magatama + amulet tradition, plan to visit both West and East Kano Shrines and use the Uraga ferry connection.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/nishi-kanou-z.html
- Official site: https://kanoujinjya.jp/

title: Kannonsaki Lighthouse (Kannonzaki Lighthouse)
datetime: Captured in the source report on 2025-12-26 19:53 (time shown in the report)
place:
Kannonsaki Lighthouse, 4-1187 Kamoi, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)
text:
Title: Kannonsaki Lighthouse (Kannonzaki Lighthouse)

Datetime:
- Captured in the source report on 2025-12-26 19:53 (time shown in the report)

Place:
- Kannonsaki Lighthouse, 4-1187 Kamoi, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)

Detail:
- **Overview:** Kannonsaki Lighthouse is known as Japan’s first Western-style lighthouse. It was built under the direction of French engineer F. L. Verny, started in 1868, and was first lit on January 1, 1869.
- **History highlights:**
- The **1st lighthouse** (brick, Western-style building) was damaged by an earthquake in April 1922.
- The **2nd lighthouse** was rebuilt in March 1923 but collapsed in the Great Kanto Earthquake (September 1923).
- The current **3rd lighthouse** (concrete) was rebuilt in June 1925.
- The start date (Nov 1) later became **“Lighthouse Memorial Day”** in Japan.
- **Access:**
- From **Keikyu Uraga Station**: bus to “Kannonzaki” (about 20 min), get off at the final stop, then walk about 10 min.
- From **JR Yokosuka Station**: bus to “Kannonzaki” (about 40 min), get off at the final stop, then walk about 10 min.
- By car: about 3 km (around 5 min) from **Mabori Kaigan IC** on the Yokohama-Yokosuka Road.
- **Admission (donation):**
- Adults: **300 JPY**
- Elementary school children and younger: **free with a guardian**
- **Opening hours:**
- **Mar–Sep**
- Weekends/holidays: 8:30–17:00
- Weekdays: 9:00–16:30
- **Oct–Feb**
- Weekends/holidays: 8:30–16:00
- Weekdays: 9:00–16:00
- Last entry is **20 minutes before closing**.
- **Closed:** Irregular (bad weather, construction, etc.)
- **Parking (around the park):**
- 4 prefectural parking lots (total **279 spaces**)
- Hours: 8:00–17:00 (Jul–Aug: 8:00–18:00); Parking Lot #1 only: 5:00–19:00
- Fees:
- **880 JPY** (regular car) on: Jan 1–3 / Apr 27–May 12 / Jul 1–Aug 31 / Nov 3
- Otherwise: weekends/holidays **550 JPY**, weekdays **free**
- **Nearby / related spots:** Yokosuka Museum of Art; Kanagawa Prefectural Kannonzaki Park; “Materia” (a sea-view restaurant); Army Pier (Rikugun Sanbashi).

Attention:
- **Accessibility:** The site is not well equipped for barrier-free access.
- No elevator or escalator; no entrance ramp measures.
- The exhibit room has a small two-step level difference; the lighthouse itself is reached by stairs.
- No wheelchair-accessible toilet, no wheelchair rental, no baby diaper-changing station, and no dedicated accessible parking.
- You can enter up to the gate from the stone-paved side.
- **Plan ahead:** Closures can happen due to weather or construction. Also note the last-entry cutoff (20 minutes before closing).

Link:
- Yokosuka City tourism page (source): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kannonzaki-toudai.html
- Official site: https://www.tokokai.org/tourlight/tourlight05/
- Contact (Tokokai, Kannonsaki branch): +81-46-841-0311

Tags: Yokosuka, Kannonzaki, Lighthouse, History, Scenic view, Kanagawa

- In rainy periods (often June), coastal paths can be slippery—use caution.

title: Kaiyama Underground Vault (Advance Reservation Only)
datetime: 2025-12-26 19:47 (captured on Yokosuka City Tourism Information website)
place:
Kaiyama Green Space (Oppama area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
Address: 5-2931-63 Uragocho, Yokosuka City
text:
Title: Kaiyama Underground Vault (Advance Reservation Only)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:47 (captured on Yokosuka City Tourism Information website)

Place:
- Kaiyama Green Space (Oppama area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address: 5-2931-63 Uragocho, Yokosuka City

Detail:
- A hand-dug underground vault (tunnel complex) excavated during World War II, located inside Kaiyama Green Space in the Oppama area.
- The total length is said to exceed about 2 km, and a portion is currently open to the public.
- Inside, you can still see room-like spaces thought to have been used as storage and meeting rooms, as well as traces of hearths.
- The Oppama area used to be a scenic coastal landscape with islands (such as Natsushima) until the early Taishō era. Later, land reclamation was carried out to build a former Imperial Japanese Navy airfield (near today’s Nissan Oppama Plant), connecting Natsushima to the mainland and turning the area into a major naval aviation base.

Attention:
- Advance reservation is required for any visit.
- Visits are guided.
- Hours: 09:00–17:00.
- Closed: Year-end and New Year holidays.
- Accessibility: Not barrier-free (no elevator/escalator/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilet; no wheelchair rental; no changing tables; no accessible parking; no tactile paving).
- Parking: Use the nearby Natsushima Urban Green Space parking area.
- Access: From Keikyu Oppama Station, take a bus and get off at “Joka Center (浄化センター)”, then walk about 5 minutes.
- For the latest conditions and reservation details, confirm via the official site or call the contact number below.

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kaiyamatikagou.html
- Official (Yokosuka City): https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/kaiyama.html
- Contact: +81-46-822-9561 (Yokosuka City Parks Management Division)

text:
Title: Hashirimizu Lower Gun Battery Site (Hashirimizu Teihoudai Ato)

Datetime:
- Open for self-guided visits on **Saturdays, Sundays, and Japanese national holidays**.
- **Mar–Oct (summer season): 09:00–17:00**
- **Nov–Feb (winter season): 09:00–16:00**
- **Closed:** Dec 29 – Jan 3
- On **weekdays**, entry is **only possible with a professional guide** (join a guided tour or consult a guide organization for a private tour).

Place:
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address: 2-698 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0811 (Japan)
- Access (public transport): From **Keikyu Mabori-Kaigan Station**, take the bus bound for **Kannonzaki** (~10 min) and get off at **“Hashirimizu Kamimachi”** bus stop.

Detail:
- A historic coastal fortification site built in the **Meiji era** and kept operational until the end of World War II.
- The remains are reported to be in good condition, with many structures still visible such as **gun emplacements**, **ammunition storage**, and **barracks**.
- Weekday visits require a guide; recommended for learning both the site’s history and surrounding nature.

Attention:
- **No parking available** on-site.
- Fees vary by guide organization and group size. As a reference, guided visits can start from **about JPY 400 per person**.
- Accessibility is limited: facilities such as elevators, escalators, wheelchair toilets, wheelchair rentals, and other barrier-free features are **not available**.
- For weekday entry, apply in advance (some guide tours require booking **up to 2 weeks before**).

Link:
- Official tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/hasirimizuteihoudaiato.html
- Site management / information: https://greenclub-yy.com/hatayamazaki/
- Guide organizations (examples):
- Sarushima Park Professional Guide Association (TEL: +81-80-6655-0557)
- Yokosuka City Guide Association (TEL: +81-46-822-8256)

Tags: Yokosuka, Hashirimizu, Historic site, Coastal fortification, Meiji era, World War II history, Guided tour, Outdoor spot

Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)
Access:
From Keikyu Maborikaigan Station: take a bus bound for “Kannonzaki” (~5 minutes), get off at “Isemachi” bus stop, then it is right nearby.
From JR Yokosuka Station: take a bus bound for “Kannonzaki” (~20 minutes), get off at “Isemachi” bus stop.

text:
Title: Hashirimizu Reservoir (Hashirimizu Suigenchi / 走水水源地)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 (timestamp shown in the source page header)

Place:
- Address: 1-2-1 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)
- Access:
- From Keikyu Maborikaigan Station: take a bus bound for “Kannonzaki” (~5 minutes), get off at “Isemachi” bus stop, then it is right nearby.
- From JR Yokosuka Station: take a bus bound for “Kannonzaki” (~20 minutes), get off at “Isemachi” bus stop.
- By car: ~500 m toward Kannonzaki from Mabori IC on the Yokohama–Yokosuka Road.

Detail:
- A historic water source developed for the Yokosuka Ironworks/Shipyard during Japan’s early modernization. Construction began in the Meiji era under the direction of French engineer François Léonce Verny.
- The brick reservoir and the concrete purification basin are designated as Registered Tangible Cultural Properties of Japan and also recognized as part of Japan Heritage, and the facility is still in active service today.
- Approximately 1,000 m³ of spring water wells up daily. It is known for being rich in minerals and tasting good.
- The spring water is nicknamed “Verny’s Water” and can be drunk from a tap inside the parking-lot area (the water is purified using a membrane filtration system).
- The site is also famous for cherry blossoms: in late March to early April, over 100 cherry trees bloom with Tokyo Bay as a backdrop.
- Opening hours (park): 08:00–17:00
- Closed days: None (open year-round)
- Parking:
- 111 spaces
- Entry: 05:00–20:00 / Exit: 05:00–21:00 (no exit possible between 21:00 and 05:00)
- Fee: +210 JPY per 30 minutes; daily cap 1,680 JPY after 3.5 hours (fees reset after midnight)
- Bicycle parking: available (free)
- Related nearby spots listed in the same source: Hashirimizu Beach, Hashirimizu Shrine, Hashirimizu Low Battery Ruins, Yokosuka Museum of Art.

Attention:
- “Verny’s Water” is available year-round except during maintenance/inspections.
- The drinking water is spring water that has been purified via membrane filtration.
- If you park a car, note the exit restriction (no exit between 21:00 and 05:00) and the midnight fee reset.
- Barrier-free facilities are listed as not available (e.g., elevator, escalator, wheelchair-accessible toilet, wheelchair rental, guidance blocks).

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/hasirimizu-suigen.html
- Official facility page (Yokosuka City): https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/hashirimizusuigenchi.html

title: Hashirimizu Beach (走水海岸), Yokosuka
place: Hashirimizu Beach (Hashirimizu Kaigan), Hashirimizu 1-16, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
text:
Title: Hashirimizu Beach (走水海岸), Yokosuka

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 (source page timestamp)

Place:
- Hashirimizu Beach (Hashirimizu Kaigan), Hashirimizu 1-16, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A shallow, calm beach on Tokyo Bay where you can watch large ships passing through the bay up close.
- Scenic views across Tokyo Bay, including Sarushima Island and the Bōsō Peninsula; Mt. Fuji may be visible in the distance on clear days.
- Popular year-round for fishing thanks to the Miura Peninsula’s relatively mild winters; seafood/live-fish restaurants operate throughout the year.
- Seasonal activities: spring cherry-blossom outings and clam digging; summer swimming/beach leisure.
- A pleasant coastal walking route runs from Mabori-kaigan toward Kannonzaki, with historic sites from ancient to modern times.
- From the slope along National Route 16 (Hashirimizu Road), you may be able to see “Diamond Fuji” (sunset aligning with Mt. Fuji’s summit) in spring and autumn; the viewpoint is recognized in the “Kantō Fuji-view 100 Scenic Spots.”
- Nearby highlights mentioned in the report:
- **Bato Kannon (Hoof Well / “Hizume-no-i”)**: a local legend about a wild horse digging with its hoof and fresh water springing out.
- **Hashirimizu Water Source (Suigenchi)**: red-brick (English-bond) buildings registered as a national Tangible Cultural Property; opened to the public during cherry-blossom season.
- **Old Waterworks Tunnel (1876)**: built to send Hashirimizu water to the shipyard (associated with engineer Verny).
- **Goshogasaki / Hashirimizu Guard Station**: said to be linked to Yamato Takeru’s expedition; later an important Edo-period maritime checkpoint.
- **Hashirimizu Shrine** and a **suikinkutsu** (water-harp) sound feature in front of the shrine.
- **Hashirimizu festival float (dashi)**: a richly carved wooden float; displayed on the 2nd Sunday from April–October and used in the main festival (every other year, mid-July weekends).
- **Kannonzaki Boardwalk**: a wooden seaside promenade with views of the Uraga Channel, where ships from around the world pass continuously.

Attention:
- **Access (public transport)**:
- From Keikyu Mabori-kaigan Station: bus bound for Kannonzaki (~5 minutes), get off at **Isecho** stop; it’s right by the beach.
- From JR Yokosuka Station: bus bound for Kannonzaki (~20 minutes), get off at **Isecho** stop.
- **Access (car)**: about 500 m toward Kannonzaki from Mabori IC on the Yokohama-Yokosuka Road.
- **Parking (Hashirimizu Suigenchi Parking)**:
- Capacity: 111 cars
- Entry: 05:00–20:00 / Exit: 05:00–21:00 (no exit allowed from 21:00 until 05:00 the next day)
- Fee: +210 JPY per 30 minutes (maximum 1,680 JPY per visit)
- If your stay crosses midnight, additional fees are charged.
- 10,000 / 5,000 / 2,000 JPY bills are not accepted for payment.
- **Barrier-free notes (as listed)**: elevators/escalators and several accessibility facilities are marked as unavailable in the report.
- **Hashirimizu Water Source (cherry-blossom opening) rules**:
- Food and drinks may be brought in, but please take all trash home.
- No pets/animals, hazardous items, or open flames.
- Smoking is prohibited except in designated areas.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/hashirimizu-beach.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, tokyo bay, beach, scenic views, mt fuji view, ships / uraga channel, fishing, swimming, clam digging, cherry blossoms, walking route, history and legends, parking info

title: Hashirimizu Shrine (Hashirimizu Jinja, 走水神社)
place:
2-12-5 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0811, Japan
Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)
text:
Title: Hashirimizu Shrine (Hashirimizu Jinja, 走水神社)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 (captured time shown in the source)

Place:
- 2-12-5 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0811, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga (Yokosuka)

Detail:
- **Overview:** A historic Shinto shrine associated with the legend of **Yamato Takeru** and **Oto Tachibana-hime**, figures from Japan’s early chronicles.
- **Origin story (legend):** It is said the shrine began when villagers placed a **“crown”** granted by Yamato Takeru into a stone chest and built a shrine building above it to enshrine him.
- **Cultural highlights:**
- A **song monument** connected to Oto Tachibana-hime was erected in **1910** within the shrine precincts; the unveiling ceremony reportedly included prominent historical figures.
- Additional monuments include a **rudder monument** (prayers for safe voyages) and a memorial mound related to culinary traditions and offerings.
- **Visiting info:**
- **Open hours (office hours):** 09:00–15:00 (worship/visiting the grounds is possible all day)
- **Closed days:** None
- **Contact:** +81-46-841-0179 (managed by Nishi Kanou Shrine)
- **Access (public transport):**
- From **Keikyu Maborikaigan Station**: take a bus bound for **Kannonzaki** (about 8 minutes), get off at **“Hashirimizu Shrine”** bus stop, then it is immediately nearby.
- From **JR Yokosuka Station**: take a bus bound for **Kannonzaki** (about 20 minutes), get off at **“Hashirimizu Shrine”** bus stop, then it is immediately nearby.

Attention:
- **Accessibility note:** The source indicates limited barrier-free facilities (e.g., no elevator/escalator, and various wheelchair-related facilities are marked as unavailable). Plan accordingly if you need step-free access.
- **Hours vs. worship:** While the grounds can be visited anytime, the stated **09:00–15:00** likely reflects office/service hours—arrive during that window if you need assistance.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/hasirimizu-z.html

Title: Sucanagosso Farmers’ Market (JA Yokosuka-Hayama)

Datetime:
- Facility information (not an event). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:37 (JST). Hours vary by season.

Place:
- Sucanagosso Farmers’ Market, 1-15-15 Nagai, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa 238-0316, Japan (Nagai–Arasaki area)

Detail:
- A direct-sales market operated by JA Yokosuka-Hayama, featuring produce from about 400 local growers. It promotes “local production for local consumption” (chisan-chisho).
- Main offerings include freshly harvested seasonal vegetables, flowers, Hayama beef, eggs, and handmade side dishes/deli items.
- Popular treat: soft-serve ice cream from the local Sekiguchi Farm.
- Hours:
- Mar–Oct: 09:30–18:00
- Nov–Feb: 09:30–17:00
- Note: the fish section (“Sakana-kan”) and snack corner close at 17:00.
- Closed: Wednesdays (open if the day is a holiday).
- Access:
- By bus: from Keikyu Misakiguchi Station, take buses bound for Yokosuka Station / Civic Hospital / Nagai / Arasaki (approx. 10 min). Get off at “Kone-gishi” bus stop, then ~1 minute walk.
- By car: from Miura-Jukan Road “Hayashi” exit, go south on Route 134 for about 3 minutes (about 1.3 km from the exit).
- Parking: 148 spaces, free.
- Accessibility (highlights):
- No elevator or escalator.
- Entrance step-free access (e.g., slope) available.
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet and ostomate-compatible toilet available.
- Wheelchair rental available.
- Baby diaper changing sheet available.
- No universal (adult) changing bed; no dedicated disabled parking noted; guidance blocks available.

Attention:
- Seasonal closing time changes (17:00 in winter). Plan shopping and meals accordingly.
- The snack corner and fish section close at 17:00 even when the market is open later.
- Closed on Wednesdays unless it’s a holiday.
- If you need an elevator/escalator, note that none are available; confirm accessibility needs in advance.

Link:
- Tourism info page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/sucanagosso.html

title: Nobi Coast / Kitashitaura Coast (Yokosuka)
datetime: 2025-12-26 20:40 (JST)  # captured time shown in the source report
place: Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama (Kitashitaura area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Nobi Coast / Kitashitaura Coast (Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 (JST)  # captured time shown in the source report

Place:
- Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama (Kitashitaura area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Nobi Coast connects seamlessly to Nagasawa and Tsukuihama, forming a calm shoreline suitable for a relaxed seaside walk.
- A seaside road along Nobi Coast runs for about 2.5 km, and a promenade is maintained from the beach near Keikyu YRP Nobi Station to the Wakayama Bokusui “couple tanka” monument.
- Across Tokyo Bay, the Boso Peninsula is visible at close range, making the area pleasant for scenic drives and cycling. Cyclist milestones are installed along the route.
- Rest shelters (gazebos) are placed along parts of the coast, allowing visitors to take breaks while enjoying the sea view.
- Nearby points of interest include:
- **Nagaoka Hantaro Memorial Museum / Wakayama Bokusui Museum**: related to the physicist Hantaro Nagaoka, who favored the area and used a local farmhouse as a villa; the building was later restored and donated to Yokosuka City.
- **Wakayama Bokusui poem monument**: a monument on the seaside promenade commemorating the poet’s connection to the area.
- **Shirohige Shrine**: surrounded by well-preserved shrine forest reportedly designated as a city natural monument.
- **Nobi Onsen (day-use hot spring)**: located along Route 134 toward Kurihama; known for a brown, bicarbonate spring often described as soft and “skin-beautifying.”
- **“30,000 Narcissus Road”**: from late January to early February, narcissus flowers bloom along roughly 2.5 km of walkway from Nobi Park to Sendagasaki (community/volunteer-led planting).

Attention:
- The coast was once known for “white sand and green pine,” but urbanization has reduced the white sand and pines are no longer seen.
- **Access**: ~7 minutes on foot from Keikyu YRP Nobi Station or Keikyu Nagasawa Station.
- **Parking (paid, ~30 cars, open 24h)**: 500 JPY for up to 1 hour (once per day); after 1 hour, 250 JPY per 30 minutes; daily cap 2,000 JPY.
- **Barrier-free notes**:
- Entrance slope/step-free measure: available
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet: available
- No elevator/escalator; no wheelchair rental; no ostomate toilet; no baby diaper-changing or adult universal changing sheet
- Accessible parking: available
- Seasonal items:
- Narcissus bloom period is limited (late Jan–early Feb).
- “Onbe-yaki” (a local New Year-style burning of old amulets/decorations) is a community event and may be held only at specific times.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kitashita-beach.html

title: Nagai Seaside Park Soleil Hill (Soleil Hill)
place: Nagai 4-chome area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (〒238-0316)
text:
Title: Nagai Seaside Park Soleil Hill (Soleil Hill)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:37 (page capture timestamp)

Place:
- Nagai 4-chome area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (〒238-0316)

Detail:
- Soleil Hill is a large seaside park on a cape with panoramic views of Sagami Bay. On clear days, you can also see Mt. Fuji and Enoshima from the Ferris wheel and the top of the athletic course. The park offers a 15m-tall adventure course, a 300m zipline, a cliffside boardwalk, seasonal flower fields (e.g., canola flowers in spring and cosmos in autumn), animal encounters, harvest and craft experiences, an indoor play facility for rainy days, camping, and a large BBQ area—making it a full-day destination for both adults and children.

Attention:
- Admission is free, but many attractions and experience programs are paid.
- Opening hours vary by season:
- Mar–Nov: 09:00–18:00
- Dec–Feb: 09:30–17:00
- Hours may change depending on the season.
- Parking (1,700 spaces):
- Regular car: ¥1,050/day
- Motorcycle: ¥400/day
- Bus: ¥2,500/day
- Bicycles and mopeds: free
- Popular attraction fees and requirements (examples):
- Large athletic course (1 hour): ¥3,200 (18+), ¥2,400 (17 and under); height 120cm+; weight under 110kg; under 17 requires guardian consent.
- Zipline: ¥1,600; height 120cm+; weight 30–110kg; under 17 requires guardian consent.
- Ferris wheel: ¥800 (high school+), ¥400 (age 3–junior high); under 3 may ride with a guardian.
- Barrier-free notes: The park is generally accessible by wheelchair, but some rides may not be usable. Wheelchair-accessible toilets, ostomate facilities, and wheelchair rental are available; there are also 35 accessible parking spaces.
- Drones are not permitted inside the park.

Link:
- Yokosuka Tourism Info page (source): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/soleil.html

- Notice (price revision for rides/coupon tickets): https://soleil-park.jp/notice/5491
- Phone: +81-46-857-2500
- Related nearby spots (as listed on the source page):
- Sukana Gosso (large farmers’ market)

title: Nagaoka Hantaro Commemorative Museum & Wakayama Bokusui Shiryokan (Yokosuka)
place:
2-6-8 Nagasawa, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0842, Japan (Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama area)
Access: 12-minute walk from Keikyu Nagasawa Station
Nearby: Nobi Coast (Kitashitaura seaside area)
text:
Title: Nagaoka Hantaro Commemorative Museum & Wakayama Bokusui Shiryokan (Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- Captured on 2025-12-26 20:39 (JST)

Place:
- 2-6-8 Nagasawa, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0842, Japan (Nobi / Nagasawa / Tsukuihama area)
- Access: 12-minute walk from Keikyu Nagasawa Station
- Nearby: Nobi Coast (Kitashitaura seaside area)

Detail:
- This small museum/memorial facility introduces physicist **Hantaro Nagaoka** and poet **Wakayama Bokusui**, and exhibits many materials and photographs that recall Bokusui’s time living in the Kitashitaura area.
- Bokusui moved to Nagasawa in March 1915 for his wife’s recuperation. During his stay, he is said to have enjoyed local food (including sardines caught along the coast), drank sake, and went fishing in the Nobi River.
- The seaside area in front of the museum is maintained as a park and has **two stone monuments of Bokusui’s poems**:
- The monument on the right (when facing the sea) is known as the **“couple monument”**, featuring Bokusui’s poem on the front and his wife Kishiko’s poem on the back. It was erected in **1953**.
- The monument on the left was erected in **1987**, and is associated with Bokusui’s poems about the Miura Peninsula coastline.
- The **Kitashitaura Bokusui Festival** is held every **September**.
- Visitor information: **Free admission**; open **09:00–16:00** (excluding the lunch break); closed **Mondays** (or the following day if Monday is a holiday) and during the **year-end/New Year** period.

Attention:
- **No on-site parking.** Use the parking lots at the **Kitashitaura Administrative Center** or the **Kitashitaura Civic Plaza**. **Large vehicles (buses, etc.) cannot be accommodated.** If you use the administrative center parking lot, you may be asked to fill in the parking log at the security office.
- Barrier-free facilities are limited on-site (e.g., no elevator, no wheelchair-accessible toilets or wheelchair rental). Accessible toilets and wheelchair rental are available at the Kitashitaura Administrative Center, and the museum can be entered step-free from that parking lot.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/bokusui.html
- Official Yokosuka City page: https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/2756/sisetu/fc00000328.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, nagasawa, nobi-coast, miura-peninsula, museum, memorial, cultural-facility, japanese-poetry, wakayama-bokusui, hantaro-nagaoka, seaside-park

datetime:

Swimming season (FY2025 / Reiwa 7): 2025-07-05 to 2025-08-31

place: Nagai / Arasaki area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Nagahama Beach (also known locally as “Nahama”)

Datetime:
- Source captured: 2025-12-26 20:39 (as shown on the report header)
- Swimming season (FY2025 / Reiwa 7): 2025-07-05 to 2025-08-31
- Beach hut open: 2025-07-05 to 2025-08-31 (08:00–17:00)

Place:
- Nagai / Arasaki area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- The official name is “Nagahama,” but locals commonly call it “Nahama.”
- A wide sandy beach with a relaxed atmosphere—especially suitable for families with children.
- A popular marine-sports spot year-round (windsurfing, yachting, sea kayaking). Even during the swimming season, these activities are enjoyed outside the designated swimming zone.
- Nearby attractions include Nagai Umi-no-te Park Soleil Hill and Arasaki Park.

Attention:
- **Access (public transit):** From Misakiguchi Station, take a bus (e.g., Arasaki / Shimin Byoin / Yokosuka Station routes; ~5 min) to “Wada,” then walk ~15 minutes.
- **Access (car):** From the Yokohama-Yokosuka Expressway Kinugasa IC via Miura Jukan Road, then Route 134 toward Misaki for ~4 km; parking available.
- **Parking (FY2025 / Reiwa 7):** Paid on specific dates; otherwise free. Paid-day hours are 07:00–18:00. The lot closes 18:00–07:00 on the evening before a paid day (no overnight parking). Capacity is ~150 vehicles; vehicles with trailers cannot be parked.
- **Facilities:** Public toilets available; no public changing rooms or showers.
- **Accessibility:** Limited barrier-free facilities (no elevators/escalators/slopes; no wheelchair-accessible toilets, etc.).
- **Keep it clean:** Please take your trash home. Fees/hours may change depending on weather or other conditions.
- **Beach hut (Wada Nagahama Gourmet Park):** Adults ¥2,000 (junior high and up), children ¥1,300 (ages 3–elementary), shower only ¥1,000. Rentals include float ring ¥1,000/day and parasol ¥1,500/day. BBQ is only for beach-hut users (reservation required); bring-your-own ingredients allowed, but trash must be taken home or disposed of using Yokosuka-designated trash bags.

Link:
- Official spot page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/nahama-beach.html
- Parking inquiries: Miura YMCA Global Eco Village (TEL +81-46-888-2100)
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Office: TEL +81-46-822-8301 (09:30–17:00)
- Beach hut site: http://www.gourmet-park.com
- Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/gourmet.park/

title: Nobi / Kitashitaura Coast “Suisen Road”: Winter Walk with 30,000 Narcissus
place: Nobi / Kitashitaura Coast “Suisen Road” (Yokosuka)
text:
Title: Nobi / Kitashitaura Coast “Suisen Road”: Winter Walk with 30,000 Narcissus

Datetime:
- Blooming status: As of 2025-02-20

Place:
- Nobi / Kitashitaura Coast “Suisen Road” (Yokosuka)

Detail:
- A coastal walking route along Nobi Beach (about 2.5 km). It’s ideal for a stroll while feeling the sea breeze.
- A promenade is developed from the seaside near YRP Nobi Station to the monument of poet Wakayama Bokusui and his wife.
- “30,000 narcissus road”: From late January to early February, delicate narcissus flowers bloom along about 2.5 km of path from Nobi Park to Sendagasaki.
- When narcissus are in full bloom, the area is filled with a clean, refreshing fragrance, and you can enjoy the contrast between the sparkling sea and white-yellow flowers.
- Also recommended for driving and cycling; cyclist milestones are installed.
- Reported bloom (Feb 20): Narcissus — Past best viewing.

Attention:
- Peak timing is usually late January to early February.
- Sea wind can be strong; bring a windproof layer.

title: Rikugun Sambashi (Army Pier), Uraga Port (Yokosuka)
place:
Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga
text:
Title: Rikugun Sambashi (Army Pier), Uraga Port (Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- Retrieved: 2025-12-26 (JST)

Place:
- Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga

Detail:
- “Rikugun Sambashi” is an L-shaped pier near the Nishi-Uraga ferry landing.
- After World War II, about **560,000** repatriates from the South Pacific and the Chinese mainland are said to have stepped onto Japan here for the first time.
- A memorial monument was installed in **October 2006** to pass down the history of repatriation through Uraga Port.
- The surrounding area has a waterfront boardwalk, and there is a gazebo where you can rest while looking across Uraga Port toward **Higashi Kanou Shrine**.

Attention:
- **No parking** is available on-site.
- Accessibility is limited: no elevators/escalators/ramps, and no wheelchair-accessible toilets or wheelchair rental are listed.
- This is a place tied to postwar repatriation history—please be respectful around the memorial.

Link:
- Spot page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/rikugunsanbashi.html
- Official site (Yokosuka City): https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5820/minato/amenity_kouen/nisiuraga/index.html
- Contact (management office): +81-46-822-4022

title: Ikazuchi Shrine (雷神社)
datetime: 2025-12-26 19:16 (JST) — extracted from Yokosuka City Tourism Information page capture timestamp
place:
Oppama/Taura area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
Address: 1-9 Oppama-honcho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa (横須賀市追浜本町1-9)
text:
Title: Ikazuchi Shrine (雷神社)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:16 (JST) — extracted from Yokosuka City Tourism Information page capture timestamp

Place:
- Oppama/Taura area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address: 1-9 Oppama-honcho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa (横須賀市追浜本町1-9)

Detail:
- Ikazuchi Shrine enshrines Honoi-kazuchi-no-mikoto (a thunder/fire deity) and is traditionally said to have been founded in 931 (Shōhei 1).
- Historical records note that rain-prayer rituals were performed at the shrine.
- In 1581 (Tenshō 9), Asakura Noto-no-kami, lord of the then Uragō village, relocated the shrine buildings from Tsukishima to the current site and revived it as “Ikazuchi Shrine.”
- A founding legend says a tremendous lightning strike hit Tsukishima where 12 maidens were in seclusion. The lightning struck a nearby Byakushin (juniper) tree, charring it black, yet the maidens were unharmed.
- On Tsukishima, the Byakushin tree remains as a sacred tree. The area was once an inlet, and Tsukishima was a small island within salt fields. Behind the “Ikazuchi Shrine Former Site Monument” (built in 1931 / Shōwa 6), there used to be a small pond.
- In the shrine precincts, a large ginkgo tree (over 500 years old) is revered; its hanging “breast-shaped” growths are objects of faith for safe childbirth and childrearing.

Attention:
- Access: From Keikyū Oppama Station, walk about 5 minutes toward Yokohama along Route 16.
- Barrier-free notes: A ramp/step-free detour route to the main hall exists, but it is a steep slope; visiting by wheelchair requires assistance. Elevators/escalators are not available, and wheelchair-accessible toilets and other related facilities are not provided.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/ikazuti-z.html
- Official site: https://kaminarijinja.com/

title: Mamonzan Navy Cemetery (Yokosuka Navy Cemetery)
place: 1-27 Negishi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area)
text:
Title: Mamonzan Navy Cemetery (Yokosuka Navy Cemetery)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:43 JST

Place:
- 1-27 Negishi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area)

Detail:
- Mamonzan Navy Cemetery was established in 1882 (Meiji 15) by Japan’s Navy Ministry as a burial ground for naval personnel who were killed in action or died in the line of duty.
- The cemetery was managed by the Yokosuka Naval District until the end of World War II (August 1945). After the war, it became a municipal cemetery, and an additional area was developed for local residents who did not have their own burial plots.
- The site covers roughly 25,000 m² of hilly terrain and is arranged in three terraced levels. The lower and middle terraces mainly contain graves of enlisted personnel, with orderly rows of headstones. The upper terrace, covered with lawn, includes seven memorial towers (cenotaphs) and graves of officers.
- Notable memorials include cenotaphs for victims of major naval incidents and conflicts (e.g., warship disasters and wartime casualties), reflecting Yokosuka’s historical role as a core naval hub.
- A memorial service is held every year in May.

Attention:
- Admission is free.
- Opening hours: 08:30–17:00 (extended hours during Obon: 08:00–18:00; during the equinoctial weeks: 08:00–17:30).
- No parking is available on site.
- Accessibility: there is a slope that allows access up to the cemetery entrance, but elevators/escalators are not available and wheelchair-accessible toilets are not provided.
- This is a cemetery and memorial site—please behave respectfully (quiet voices, no littering, and follow any on-site rules).
- Contact (Yokosuka City Health General Affairs Division): Tel +81-46-824-7502 / Email hga-hd@city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/mamonzan.html
- http://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/3110/sisetu/fc00001136.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, History, Culture, Memorial, Navy, Cemetery, Accessible-route-to-entrance

title: Magaibutsu (Cliff-Carved Buddha) on Mt. Takatori (Takatori-yama)
place: Mt. Takatori (Elevation: 139 m), Oppama / Taura area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
text:
Title: Magaibutsu (Cliff-Carved Buddha) on Mt. Takatori (Takatori-yama)

Datetime:
- Retrieved: 2025-12-26 20:38 (JST)

Place:
- Mt. Takatori (Elevation: 139 m), Oppama / Taura area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Mt. Takatori is a 139-meter rocky mountain known for steep cliffs, sometimes nicknamed “Shonan Myogi” because its rugged silhouette resembles Mt. Myogi in Gunma.
- On the rock face, a giant image of **Miroku Bosatsu (Maitreya Bodhisattva)** is carved directly into the cliff. It was created by Yokosuka-based sculptor **Shigeru Fujishima**, starting in 1960 (Showa 35), and took about a year to complete.
- The carving is massive: approximately **8 m tall** and **4.5 m wide**.
- A separate cliff-carved statue of **Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni Tathagata)** once existed, but it was demolished in 1965 (Showa 40) due to the construction of Takatori Elementary School.
- The mountain’s soft tuff rock (common in Yokosuka) was historically quarried as “Takatori stone” for construction materials, which helped create the dramatic vertical rock walls seen today.
- Numerous small holes on the rock surface are said to be traces of pitons driven in for climbing practice.

Attention:
- **No parking available.**
- Accessibility is limited: the site is **not barrier-free** (no elevators, escalators, ramps), and there are **no wheelchair-accessible toilets**, ostomate toilets, wheelchair rentals, diaper-changing sheets, universal changing sheets, accessible parking spaces, or tactile paving blocks.

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/magaibutu.html
- Yokosuka City (official): http://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/fc00000978.html
- Contact (Yokosuka City Park Management Division): Tel +81-46-822-8333 / Email pa-ep@city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp

title: Takatoriyama Park (Takatoriyama Koen)
datetime:
2025-12-26 (information snapshot date shown in the source)

place: Shonan Takatori 3-3-520, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Oppama/Taura area)
text:
Title: Takatoriyama Park (Takatoriyama Koen)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 (information snapshot date shown in the source)
- Safety update: 2025-12-05 (progress report date shown in the source)

Place:
- Shonan Takatori 3-3-520, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Oppama/Taura area)

Detail:
- A mountain park at about 139 m elevation, known for steep rock faces and panoramic views. On clear days, you can see Mt. Fuji as well as the Izu, Hakone, and Boso areas.
- The summit area includes a rocky peak with an observation point.
- A large cliff-carved Buddhist relief (Miroku Bosatsu) is one of the park’s highlights (approximately 8 m tall).
- The area’s distinctive landscape was shaped by historical quarrying of “Takatori stone,” once used for fire-resistant building materials and even Tokyo Bay fort construction.
- A seasonal hiking route traditionally connects Takatoriyama to Jimmuji Temple.

Attention:
- Hiking course partial closure: the section between the cliff Buddha area and the water distribution reservoir is closed due to rockfalls; reopening is undecided. The cliff Buddha can still be viewed.
- Rock climbing is generally prohibited in the park; exceptions require following official guidance and registering with the local safety council.
- No parking available.
- Drones (and similar devices) are not permitted in the park.
- Accessibility: the source indicates no elevators/escalators/ramps and no wheelchair-accessible restrooms or wheelchair rental.

Link:
- Tourist info page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/takatoriyama-park.html
- Official city page: http://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/5560/sisetu/fc00000978.html
